building inspector shall revoke or suspend the site development permit.
   (B)   Procedure For Revoking Site Development Permit: No site development
permit shall be permanently revoked or suspended until a hearing is held by the
plan commission. Written notice of such hearing shall be served upon the
permittee, either personally or by certified mail, return receipt requested,
and shall state:
      1.   The grounds for complaint or reasons for the revocation or
suspension, in clear and concise language.
      2.   The time when, and the place where, such hearing is to be held. Such
notice shall be served by mailing by certified mail or personal service on the
permittee at least five (5) days prior to the date set for the hearing. At any
such hearing, the permittee shall be given an opportunity to be heard, and he
may call witnesses and present evidence on his behalf. Upon conclusion of such
hearing, the plan commission shall determine whether or not the permit shall be
suspended or revoked.
      3.   The plan commission shall hold the hearing to consider
recommendations for revocation or suspension of permits which have been
temporarily suspended at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the plan
commission at which all conditions of subsection (B)2 of this section can be
fulfilled. (Ord. O-4-16-8, 5-2-2016)
4-3-18: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
   (A)   Standards And Specifications: All nonexempt developments, as set forth
in this chapter, shall comply with the standards and specifications set forth
by provisions of this chapter. It shall be unlawful for any person to initiate
such site development activities without a site development permit or building
permit or to carry on such site development activities other than as provided
in an approved site development plan. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any
property improved, graded, or developed pursuant to this chapter to alter or
change such site in contravention of the site development plan or allow the
site to remain in a condition which does not conform to the site development
plan.
   (B)   Penalties: Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, shall be liable to a fine or penalty
up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and each day of violation shall be
deemed a separate offense. This penalty provision shall be in addition to all
other rights and remedies which the village may have, at law or equity, for an
injunction or other remedy and the village may pursue all remedies available to
it in a court or courts of law concurrently with proceeding to impose the
penalties contained therein. (Ord. O-4-16-8, 5-2-2016)
CHAPTER 4
VACANT LOTS AND BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Definitions
4-4-2: Declaration Of Vacant Buildings
4-4-3: Obligation To Register Vacant Building And Vacant Lot
4-4-4: Vacant Building/Lot Registration Application
4-4-5: Fee
4-4-6: Changes In Registration Information
4-4-7: Responsibilities Of The Owner
4-4-8: Promulgation Of Rules And Regulations
4-4-9: Enforcement And Penalties
4-4-10: Discharge Of Obligation To Register Vacant Building Or Vacant Lot
4-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
BUILDING: Any business or commercial structure or any single-family or multi-
family residential structure occupied or intended for supporting or sheltering
any occupancy.
BUILDING OFFICER: The Village's building officer or inspector, or his designee.
EVIDENCE OF VACANCY: Any condition that on its own or combined with other
conditions present would lead a reasonable person to believe that the property
is vacant. Such conditions include, but are not limited to, the following:
   (A)   Substantially all lawful residential or business activity has ceased.
   (B)   The percentage of the overall square footage of occupied to unoccupied
space or the overall number of occupied and unoccupied units.
   (C)   The building is substantially devoid of contents.
   (D)   The condition and value of fixtures or personal property in the
building.
   (E)   Lack of utility services (water, sewer, electric or natural gas).
   (F)   The building is the subject of a foreclosure action.
   (G)   The presence or recurrence of uncorrected Code violations.
   (H)   Overgrown and/or dead vegetation.
   (I)   Accumulation of newspapers, circulars, flyers and/or mail.
   (J)   Abandonment by owner.
OWNER: Any person, agent, operator, firm, or corporation having a legal or
equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the
State, County, or Village as holding title to the property; or otherwise having
control of the property, including the guardian of the estate of any such
person, the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered
to take possession of real property by a court; or any person maintaining,
operating, or collecting rent.
PERSON: Any corporation, partnership, or other entity as well as any
individual.
UNOCCUPIED: Any business or commercial structure or any single- family or
multi-family residential structure which is vacant, lacks the habitual presence
of human beings who have a legal right to be on the premises, and is not
maintained pursuant to the minimum standards as set forth in the Property
Maintenance Code.
VACANT BUILDING: Any business or commercial structure or any single-family or
multi-family residential structure which is:
   (A)   Unoccupied and unsecured;
   (B)   Unoccupied and secured by boarding or other similar means;
   (C)   Unoccupied and a dangerous structure;
   (D)   Unoccupied and condemned by the building officer pursuant to
applicable law;
   (E)   Unoccupied and has multiple Code violations;
   (F)   Unoccupied and the building or its premises has been the site of
unlawful activity within the previous six (6) months;
   (G)   Condemned by the building officer and unlawfully occupied;
   (H)   Unoccupied for more than ninety (90) days, during which time the
building officer has issued an order to correct public nuisance conditions and
said conditions have not been corrected in a Code- compliant manner;
   (I)   Unoccupied for more than six (6) consecutive months; and/or
   (J)   Abandoned by persons who surrender their claim, right, or interest in
the property.
Vacant building shall not include unoccupied buildings which are undergoing
construction, renovation, or rehabilitation and which are in compliance with
all applicable Village ordinances, codes, and regulations, and for which
construction, renovation or rehabilitation is proceeding diligently to
completion, or a building that has been used as a residence by a person
entitled to possession for a period of at least three (3) months within a
previous nine (9) month period and a person entitled to possession intends to
resume residing at the property.
Vacant building shall encompass an entire strip- store, shopping plaza,
shopping center, mini-mall, or industrial condo, even though some parts of the
same may contain multiple divisible units that may be occupied or unoccupied,
or vacant or partially vacant, so long as the building is under one (1) roof,
owned by the same person, and otherwise meets the definition of a vacant
building or has been declared to be a vacant building.
VACANT LOT: Any lot on which there are no permanent buildings or on which there
is a permanent building in the process of construction but which has had no
building activity or construction for at least one (1) consecutive month prior.
Vacant lot shall not include lots for which construction on the lot is
proceeding diligently to completion or a lot on which a majority of the lot is
utilized for agricultural purposes. (Ord. O-3-17-8, 4-3-2017)
4-4-2: DECLARATION OF VACANT BUILDINGS:
   (A)   Evaluation: The building officer may evaluate buildings in the Village
which do not meet the definition of a vacant building and, based on evidence of
vacancy factors, make a declaration that the building is a vacant building. Any
such declaration shall be made in writing and shall state the factual basis.
   (B)   Notice: Within seven (7) days of making a declaration, the building
officer shall send a notice of declaration, including the factual basis
therefor, to the owner. The notice of declaration shall be served by certified
mail, return receipt requested, by personal or substitute service, or posted in
a conspicuous location on the building if the owner is unknown. The notice
shall contain a statement of the obligations of the owner of a building
determined to be a vacant building, a copy of the vacant building/lot
registration application, and a notice of the owner's right to appeal the
building officer's declaration.
   (C)   Appeal Of Declaration: An owner of a building declared by the building
officer to be a vacant building as provided for in this section may appeal such
declaration. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the
Village Clerk within fifteen (15) days after the date of service of the notice
of declaration. The filing of an appeal shall stay the owner's obligation to
register the building pursuant to this chapter. The appeal shall contain a
statement setting out all of the reasons the owner disputes the declaration,
setting forth specific facts in support thereof, and including all evidence the
owner relies upon in support of their appeal. The appeal shall be resolved
based solely upon: 1) the evidence submitted by the owner in filing his appeal,
2) the building officer's written declaration, and 3) any evidence presented at
a hearing if the owner affirmatively demands such a hearing. If the owner does
request a hearing, the Village Clerk shall set a hearing date and notify the
owner.
   (D)   Grounds For Appeal: Any appeal from the building officer's declaration
shall be strictly limited to the issue of whether the building should be deemed
to be a vacant building.
   (E)   Decision: The Village Clerk shall send written notice of the Village's
decision to the owner within fifteen (15) days after such a decision has been
made. (Ord. O-3-17-8, 4-3-2017)
4-4-3: OBLIGATION TO REGISTER VACANT BUILDING AND VACANT LOT:
   (A)   Any owner of a vacant building or vacant lot shall, within thirty (30)
days after the building becomes vacant or is declared vacant, or within thirty
(30) days after the effective date of this chapter, whichever is later,
complete a vacant building/lot registration application and register such
vacant building or vacant lot with the building officer.
   (B)   Registration of a vacant building or lot pursuant to this chapter
shall not exonerate the owner of their duty to comply with all applicable codes
and ordinances, and shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other
applicable ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations which prescribe
standards other than as provided in this chapter.
   (C)   If multiple individual units meet the definition of a vacant building
in a strip-store, shopping plaza, shopping center, mini- mall, or industrial
condo, but not all such units are owned by a single person, each individual
unit shall be considered a separate vacant building for registration purposes.
(Ord. O-3-17-8, 4-3-2017)
4-4-4: VACANT BUILDING/LOT REGISTRATION APPLICATION:
   (A)   Each vacant building/lot registration application shall be made in
writing to the building officer on a form provided for that purpose, and shall
contain:
      1.   The property identification number (PIN), common address, and lot
number for the property, as well as a physical description of the vacant
building, including but not limited to construction materials and color;
      2.   The name, street address, and telephone number of the owner, or else
of another person twenty one (21) years of age or older who has been designated
by the owner as the owner's authorized agent for receiving notices of Code
violations and service of process in any court proceedings or administrative
enforcement proceedings which may arise in connection with the enforcement of
this chapter. By designating an authorized agent pursuant to this section, the
owner consents to receive any and all notices of Code violations concerning the
registered building or lot and all process in any court proceeding or
administrative enforcement proceeding brought to enforce this Code concerning
the registered building or lot by service of the notice or process on the
authorized agent;
      3.   An emergency contact name and telephone number;
      4.   The case name and number of any litigation pending that concerns or
affects the vacant building or lot, including bankruptcy or foreclosure cases;
      5.   The name, street address, and telephone number of all persons with
any legal interest in the vacant building or lot;
      6.   The type, location, and amount of any toxic, flammable or hazardous
materials stored or used in or on the vacant building or lot, if applicable;
      7.   Any other relevant information about the vacant building or lot that
may be necessary or useful for police, paramedics, the Fire Department, or
other emergency responders, if applicable.
   (B)   Any owner who fails to register a vacant building or lot under the
provisions of this chapter shall further be deemed to have consented to receive
any and all notices of Code violations and all process in any legal or
administrative proceedings which may be brought to enforce any Code provisions
concerning the building or lot by posting of the same at or on such vacant
building or lot. (Ord. O-3-17-8, 4-3-2017)
4-4-5: FEE:
   (A)   There shall be no fee to register a vacant building.
   (B)   There shall be no fee to register a vacant lot.
   (C)   An owner shall be required to annually re-register the vacant building
or vacant lot on the anniversary of the date of registration as long as the
building remains a vacant building or remains a vacant lot as defined in this
chapter. (Ord. O-3-17-8, 4-3-2017)
4-4-6: CHANGES IN REGISTRATION INFORMATION:
An owner of any building or lot registered pursuant to this chapter shall
notify the building officer within twenty one (21) days of any change in the
registration information by filing an amended registration statement on an
application provided by the building officer. A new registration is required
for any change in ownership whatsoever. The registration statement shall be
deemed prima facie proof of the statements therein contained in any
administrative enforcement proceeding or court proceeding instituted by the
Village against the owner of the building. (Ord. O-3-17-8, 4-3-2017)
4-4-7: RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE OWNER:
   (A)   An owner of any vacant building shall, within thirty (30) days of the
building becoming vacant, enclose and secure the building and maintain the
building in a secure and closed condition until the building no longer meets
the definition of a vacant building. A building shall be deemed secured and
closed if the building is maintained pursuant to the minimum standards as set
forth in the Property Maintenance Code and as follows:
      1.   Building Openings: Doors, windows, areaways and other openings are
weathertight and secured against entry by birds, vermin and trespassers.
Missing or broken doors, windows and opening coverings are covered with at
least one-half inch (1/2") of plywood or structural wood panel, weather
protected, tightly fitted to the opening and secured by screws or bolts.
      2.   Roofs: The roof and flashings are sound, tight, will not admit
moisture, and have been drained as necessary to prevent dampness or
deterioration in the walls or interior.
      3.   Drainage: The building gutters and downspouts are watertight and
entire storm drainage system is adequately sized, installed in an approved
manner, functional and discharged in an approved manner.
      4.   Building Structure: The building is maintained in good repair,
structurally sound, free from debris, rubbish and garbage, and sanitary, and
interior floors, walking surfaces and stairs are structurally sound, and
interior walls and ceilings are free of loose or hanging plaster and finishes,
so as not to pose a threat to the public health or safety.
      5.   Structural Members: The structural members are free of deterioration
and capable of safely bearing imposed dead and live loads.
      6.   Foundation Walls: The foundation walls are plumb, free from open
cracks and breaks, and ratproof.
      7.   Exterior Walls: The exterior walls are free of holes, breaks, and
loose or rotting materials. Exposed metal and wood surfaces are protected from
the elements and against decay or rust by periodic application of weather
coating materials, such as paint or similar surface treatment.
      8.   Decorative Features: The cornices, belt courses, corbels, terra
cotta trim, wall facings and similar decorative features are safe, anchored,
and in good repair. Exposed metal and wood surfaces are protected from the
elements and against decay or rust by periodic application of weather coating
materials, such as paint or similar surface treatment.
      9.   Structure Extensions: All balconies, porches, canopies, marquees,
signs, metal awnings, cornices, stairways, fire escapes, standpipes, exhaust
ducts and similar features are in good repair, anchored, safe and sound.
Exposed metal and wood surfaces are protected from the elements and against
decay or rust by periodic application of weather coating materials, such as
paint or similar surface treatment.
      10.   Chimneys And Towers: Chimneys, cooling towers, smokestacks, and
similar appurtenances are structurally safe. Exposed metal and wood surfaces
are protected from the elements and against decay or rust by periodic
application of weather coating materials, such as paint or similar surface
treatment.
      11.   Sidewalk Openings: Yard-walks, steps, and openings in sidewalks are
safe for pedestrian travel.
      12.   Accessory And Appurtenant Structures: Accessory and appurtenant
structures such as garages, sheds, and fences are free from safety, health, and
fire hazards.
   (B)   An owner of any vacant building or lot shall also:
      1.   Keep the premises on which a building is located clean; safe and
sanitary; Village Code compliant with respect to weeds; and free of dead
vegetation, trash, junk, debris, building materials, junk cars, furniture,
clothing, appliances and litter, including but not limited to the accumulation
of newspapers, circulars and flyers.
      2.   Keep the property maintained free of graffiti, tagging, or similar
markings.
      3.   Keep the yard landscaped and maintained.
      4.   Keep pools and spas in working order so the water is not stagnant
and remains clear and free of pollutants and debris, or drained and kept dry.
      5.   Disconnect water at the buffalo box.
      6.   Maintain an operable sump pump, if applicable.
      7.   Provide and maintain winterization of the building between November
1 and March 31. (Ord. O-3-17-8, 4-3-2017)
4-4-8: PROMULGATION OF RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The building officer may issue rules and regulations for the administration of
this chapter. These rules may designate materials and methods which must be
used to secure a building. (Ord. O-3-17-8, 4-3-2017)
4-4-9: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
   (A)   Failure To Register Vacant Building/Lot: The Village shall send a
notice to the owner by certified mail, return receipt requested, by personal or
substitute service, or posted in a conspicuous location on the building if the
owner is unknown, informing him of his failure to complete a vacant building/
lot registration application or register the vacant building or vacant lot. The
owner shall have fourteen (14) days in which to complete a vacant building/lot
registration application or register the vacant building or vacant lot as set
forth in the notice. If the violation is not resolved within fourteen (14)
days, the owner shall be sentenced and fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code for each offense, provided however that such sentence shall
not constitute the exclusive remedy of the Village and the Village will remain
entitled to pursue any and all legal or equitable relief.
   (B)   Other Violations: Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects
or refuses to comply with any provision of this chapter other than the
registration requirement shall be sentenced as provided in section
 1-4-1 of this Code for each offense, provided however that such sentence shall
not constitute the exclusive remedy of the Village and the Village will remain
entitled to pursue any and all legal or equitable relief, including but not
limited to: injunctive relief, application to a court of competent jurisdiction
for a receiver, demolition, or condemnation, contracting for the repair or
purchase of the premises, or foreclosure of any lien the Village may have
thereon.
   (C)   Authority Of Village: Nothing herein contained shall prohibit the
Village from condemning a vacant building as provided by applicable law or
taking other actions upon a determination that the building is a public
nuisance or poses an imminent danger to the occupants of the building, or the
public health, safety and welfare. (Ord. O-3-17-8, 4-3-2017)
4-4-10: DISCHARGE OF OBLIGATION TO REGISTER VACANT BUILDING OR VACANT LOT:
Before the removal of a vacant building or lot from the vacant building/lot
registry and/or the occupancy of a previously vacant building will be
permitted, the owner must fully resolve all condition(s) which initially
compelled registration of the vacant building or lot, must secure an inspection
to determine compliance with the minimum levels of habitability as set forth in
title 4, chapter 1 of this Code, and must fully pay all Village fees, fines,
and costs, as required. (Ord. O-3-17-8, 4-3-2017)
CHAPTER 5
FENCE REGULATIONS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Definitions
4-5-2: Construction And Maintenance
4-5-3: Barbed, Razor, Concertina Or Similar Wire And Electrified Electrical
Fences
4-5-4: Height And Location
4-5-5: Permits
4-5-6: Public Nuisance; Penalties And Remedies
4-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
 
CORNER For buildings on comer lots, the side of residence that abuts a street but is
LOT\   not used for the residential address. On a comer lot, side yard shall be used
SIDE   to describe that side of the residence that does not abut a street.
YARD:
       Any structure, partition or enclosure, and it's hardware: rails, pickets,
       panels, braces, posts, brackets, hinges and such; of wood, iron, metal, or
       other material, enclosing or dividing a piece of land. Hedges, plantings,
       shrubbery, etc., when used as a screen, partition, enclosure, or indication
       of property division are for this regulation considered fences.
       (A)   Barbed, Razor, Concertina or Similar Wire Fence: Any wire or device
       designed to, and/or inflict physical, bodily harm to a living physical entity
       as in, but not limited to, piercing, cutting or abrading.
       (B)   Electrified Fence: Any wire or device designed to and/or transmit an
FENCE: electric charge, continuous or pulsed, stimulating a physical reaction or
       harm in a living physical entity when contact is made with such a device.
       (C)   Hidden Fence: Any device, physical or electronic designed to control
       entry or exit of a living physical entity that is not readily observed or
       detected by normal sensory perception. Typically, but not limited to motion,
       radio waves, infra red, sonic and optical.
       (D)   Shared Fence: Any part or section of fencing that is used by both
       neighboring parties. See section
       4-5-4(E) for individual party agreements and responsibilities. (Ord. O-11-17-
       1, 11-20-2017; amd. Ord. 0-4-23-1, 4-3-2023)
 
4-5-2: CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE:
   (A)   A fence shall be maintained and trimmed to the maximum height as set
forth in this chapter. (Ord. 0-11-17- 1,11-20-2017)
   (B)   Fences shall be erected so that all supporting members shall be
attached to and located within the lot line fenced. All wooden fences shall be
constructed in such a manner that the finished side faces to the exterior of
the lot fenced.
   (C)   All fences shall be constructed in conformity with wind, stress,
foundational, structural, and other requirements of the building codes and
ordinances of the Village of Grant Park.
   (D)   All fences shall be maintained in a good and structurally sound
manner, and be capable of supporting imposed loads. All fence surfaces shall be
maintained in a good, clean and sanitary condition.
   (E)   All fences that are painted, stained or have any type coatings shall
be of one color whether solid, transparent or translucent in a natural tone or
color. Advertising, murals, artwork and/or odd colors of such are not permitted
in residential areas or zones on the exterior faced side of any such fence.
   (F)   Business or Industrial area or zone must attain written Village Board
approval prior to applying any advertising or artwork to the fences. The
Village may require descriptive renderings prior to such approval. Temporary
advertising for help or postings to fill a employment position are allowed and
exempt from such requirements.
   (G)   Peeling, chipping, flaked or abraded paint shall not be permitted.
Rusted, corroded, decayed or rotted fences, or parts of fences, shall not be
permitted. All fences, or parts of fences, shall be maintained free of holes,
breaks, missing parts and otherwise securely fastened to any supporting member.
Such defects shall be repaired or replace immediately. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-
2017; amd. Ord. 0-4-23-1, 4-3-2023)
4-5-3: BARBED, RAZOR, CONCERTINA OR SIMILAR WIRE AND ELECTRIFIED FENCES:
   (A)   No barbed, razor, concertina or similar wire or electrified fences
shall be allowed on private property in residential areas or zones. No barbed,
razor, concertina or similar wire_or electrified fences shall be allowed on
private property in a front yard of any commercial or industrial areas or zones
or where the property lines of such property abut a residential area or zone.
   (B)   The use of barbed, razor, concertina or similar wire is prohibited in
industrial areas or zones except for the top one foot (T) of any fence along
the side or rear lot lines in these areas or zones. Barbed, razor, concertina
or similar wire shall not be used, installed or constructed on fences fronting
on any street.
   (C)   Use of hidden fences are permitted only within the owners property
limits and may not extend into other areas. Such fencing shall not interfere
with the normal operation of any other physical or electrical device. Fencing
that is found to interfere with such physical or electrical operations shall
immediately be removed or permanently disconnected. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-
2017; amd. Ord. 0-4-23-1, 4-3-2023)
4-5-4: HEIGHT AND LOCATION:
It shall be unlawful to maintain or construct any fence and it's parts composed
in whole part or section in excess of the height as set forth below:
   (A)   Back And Side Yards: In all zones but industrial, the maximum height
of fences and it's parts, in back and side yards, shall be six feet (6'). In
industrial zones, the maximum height of fences and it's parts shall be ten feet
(10') including any barb, razor, concertina or similar wire, if used, as
identified in 4-5-3(B). The height of the fence shall be determined as the
distance between the natural ground level and the highest projection or the top
of the fence, whichever is greater.
   (B)   Front Yards: In front yards, the maximum height of fences and it's
parts shall be thirty six inches (36"). However, no fence and it's parts shall
exceed two feet (2') in height within thirty feet (30') of a street
intersection.
   (C)   Comer Lot Side Yards: For a determination of fence locations for a
comer lot, the street address will determine the front of the home. A fence may
continue into the side yard of the comer lot a maximum ten feet (10') from the
home with a maximum height of six feet (6'). Any fence or it's parts located
farther than ten feet (1 O') from the home into the side yard of the comer lot
may be installed at a four foot (4') maximum height provided it is at least
fifty percent (50%) open. No chainlink fences will be allowed in the side yard
of a comer lot. No fence may be located within five feet (5') of any sidewalk
or located closer than seventeen feet (17') from the edge of a curb line,
whichever is more restrictive.
   (D)   Lot Lines And Rights-Of-Way: Where allowed, fences and it's parts may
be constructed on lot lines with no part exceeding the lot line as long as the
fence does not interfere with or obstruct a public right-of-way or prevent
access to any public utility apparatus. All gates or such features shall swing
or open toward the owners property as not to interfere with any other property.
In the event that the owner desires to construct a fence upon a public utility
right-of-way, the owner shall assume all costs associated with the removal, and
the Village shall not be held liable for damages by permitting the fence to be
constructed on or over the right-of-way. The owner shall assume the
responsibility to notify all utility companies of the intent to erect a fence
upon a public utility right-of- way.
   (E)   Shared Fence or a shared portion of a fence by a lot line is
permitted. However, the shared fence may not exceed one of the properties lot
line of any one individual owner. Use as a shared fence must be with a written
contract of possession, use and repair responsibilities between property
owners. A copy of the contract must be filed with the Village Clerk. Such a
contract is not transferable to a new property owner and must be reinstated
with the new property owner if so desired. Any change or alteration of the
contract must be in writing with such changes added to the contract and again
filed with the Village Clerk. Failure to do so may result in a citation of
violation.
   (F)   Drainage Easements: Fences shall not be located in any drainage
easement, unless authorized by the Village Engineer and the Building Director.
(Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017; amd. Ord. 0-4-23-1, 4-3-2023)
4-5-5: PERMITS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect a fence in the Village without
first obtaining a building permit from the Director of Building and Zoning.
Before a permit is issued, the owner must show positive proof of the lot line
by survey or location of lot line stakes. All fences that enclose swimming
pools shallbe governed by section
4-9-1 of this title. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017; amd. Ord. 0-4-23-1, 4-3-2023)
4-5-6: PUBLIC NUISANCE; PENALTIES AND REMEDIES:
   (A)   Any fence found to be in violation of this chapter shall be declared a
public nuisance.
   (B)   If the Director of Building and Zoning and/or the Village Board, by
majority vote, determines that any fence for any reason constitutes a public
nuisance, the Village will notify the owner of the premises of such a
determination, by certified mail, and require the owner to remove, obtain a
permit or make any necessary repairs or improvements to the fence within
fifteen (15) days. Should the owner fail to abate the nuisance within fifteen
(15) days from the date of notice, the Director of Building and Zoning shall be
authorized to issue a citation for a violation of this chapter. Additionally,
the Director of Building and Zoning and/or the Village Clerk may file a
complaint in the Circuit Court of Kankakee County fora court order to abate the
nuisance.
   (C)   The property owner is responsible for adherence to all ordinances and
building codes. The ordinance and building codes override any permission or
approvals by any other individual or authority.
   (D)   Any person found in violation of this chapter shall be fined court
costs and no less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) or more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day a violation continues shall constitute a
separate offense. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017; amd. Ord. 0-4-23-1, 4-3-2023)
CHAPTER 6
SIDEWALK REGULATIONS
SECTION:
4-6-1: Sidewalk Required
4-6-2: Sidewalk Construction Specifications
4-6-3: Tract Of Land Defined
4-6-4: Corner Lots
4-6-5: Maintenance Of Sidewalks
4-6-6: Exemptions
4-6-7: Enforcement
4-6-8: Penalty
4-6-1: SIDEWALK REQUIRED:
Prior to conveyance of any tract of land on which a structure or building is in
existence, or prior to the occupancy or use of any new building or structure,
the seller as to conveyance and owner as to occupancy or use shall install
sidewalks according to the specifications as set forth in this chapter on that
portion of their premises fronting a public street in the Village.
   (A)   Sidewalks shall be installed before transfer of ownership.
Circumstances such as weather or future Village improvements plans may
necessitate escrow monies to be held by the Village and construction of
sidewalks to be completed at a later date, as determined by the Code
Enforcement Officer and under the direction of the Village.
   (B)   The amount of escrow monies to be held by the Village shall be
determined by the Code Enforcement Officer using a prevailing rate (verified
annually) for such sidewalk construction and based on actual footage of
property involved plus the cost of a building permit. A contract signed by
sellers, buyers, and the Village shall list all correct information regarding
the cost and placement of sidewalks. Once this contract is signed and the
escrow funds have been deposited with the Village, the requirements of this
subsection and subsections (A) and (C) of this section shall be considered
fulfilled. The Village shall assume responsibility for installation of said
sidewalk in a timely manner.
   (C)   All sidewalk construction shall require a permit as obtained through
the Grant Park Building Department. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-6-2: SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS:
Sidewalks shall consist of concrete and shall be a minimum of five feet (5') in
width and four inches (4") in depth and shall be located parallel to the
property line; provided, however, if there is in existence a structure,
building, or tree, said sidewalks shall be installed in a manner which will
comply with the requirement of being as parallel to the property line as is
feasible; and said sidewalks shall be located one foot (1') outside the
property line, except in subdivisions where sidewalks have been constructed
otherwise, in which instance a sidewalk shall conform to such existing
sidewalks.
As used in this chapter, a "conveyance" is hereby defined as including
transfers of ownership by deed or by assignment of beneficial interest in a
land trust, or by entering into an installment contract for deed, whether said
agreement is recorded or unrecorded. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-6-3: TRACT OF LAND DEFINED:
As used in this chapter, "tract of land" is hereby defined to include any lot
or tract of land located within the Village limits, and adjoining lots or
parcels of land owned by the same person and fronting the same public street
shall be considered one tract of land for purposes of this chapter. (Ord. O-11-
17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-6-4: CORNER LOTS:
On corner lots in the Village, sidewalks shall be installed on both frontages
abutting the public streets. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-6-5: MAINTENANCE OF SIDEWALKS:
The owner of any lot on which a sidewalk is installed shall maintain said
sidewalk in a manner which ensures the safe and beneficial use of said sidewalk
by the residents of the Village and the general public. No sidewalk shall be
removed by any person unless a replacement sidewalk is installed within thirty
(30) days of the date of such removal. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-6-6: EXEMPTIONS:
The following shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter:
   (A)   Unimproved lots or tracts of land not falling within the definition in
section
4-6-3 of this chapter.
   (B)   Any lot or tract of land, on which, in the opinion of the Village Code
Enforcement Officer, it is not structurally feasible for the placement of
sidewalks along the lot frontage of the public street due to the terrain or
placement of preexisting trees or other major improvements. (Ord. O-11-17-1,
11-20-2017)
4-6-7: ENFORCEMENT:
Enforcement of the provisions of this chapter shall rest with the local
building inspector. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-6-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provisions of this chapter, upon conviction, shall be
subject to a fine according to section
1-4-1 of this Code, and each day that said violation continues shall be
considered a separate offense. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
CHAPTER 7
ANTIMONOTONY CODE
SECTION:
4-7-1: Purpose
4-7-2: Similarity In Appearance Prohibited In Residential Construction
4-7-3: Standards For Determining Similarity In Appearance
4-7-4: Administration And Enforcement; Appeals
4-7-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to create an aesthetically pleasing character of
the single-family residential districts in the Village in order to protect and
enhance property values. The construction of single-family residences which are
substantially similar in appearance to other nearby single-family residences
are prohibited in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. O-11-
17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-7-2: SIMILARITY IN APPEARANCE PROHIBITED IN RESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION:
   (A)   No building permit shall be issued for any new detached single-family
dwelling units in the R-1 or R-2 Zoning Districts (the "subject lot") which is
similar in front facade appearance to any dwelling unit meeting the following
requirements:
      1.   The subject lot shall be dissimilar to dwelling units within two (2)
lots on either side on the same side of the street;
      2.   The subject lot shall be dissimilar to dwelling units directly
across the street and within one lot thereof;
      3.   With respect to lots with frontage on the bulb of a cul-de- sac, the
subject lot shall be dissimilar to dwelling units within one lot on either side
of the subject lot or directly across the cul-de-sac from the subject lot.
      4.   With respect to front yards, in the event the lot adjacent on either
side of the subject lot, the lot directly across the street or the lot adjacent
on either side of that lot directly across the street from the subject lot has
a different yard type (i.e., side, rear) adjacent to the shared street, then
the restrictions shall not apply to those lots.
      5.   When calculating lots for purposes of dissimilarity, an intervening
street shall be counted as one lot;
      6.   When calculating lots for purposes of dissimilarity, lots shall not
be restricted if separated from the subject lot by a collector road.
   (B)   On corner lots, no building permit shall be issued for any new
detached single-family dwelling unit in the R-1 and R-2 Zoning Districts which
are similar in side facades. On lots backing up to a public right-of-way or
secondary road, no building permit shall be issued for any new detached single-
family dwelling unit in the R-1 or R-2 Zoning District which are similar in
rear facades; except when there is an approved landscape berm or plan, approved
by the Board of Trustees.
   (C)   A dwelling on a corner lot may be considered dissimilar to another if
the front of the two (2) dwelling units face different streets.
   (D)   Dwelling units must comply with the dissimilarity provisions which are
applicable to the front facade, side facades, and rear facade. (Ord. O-11-17-1,
11-20-2017)
4-7-3: STANDARDS FOR DETERMINING SIMILARITY IN APPEARANCE:
         (A)   Distinguishing Characteristics, Front Facade: For the purpose of
this chapter, the term "similar in appearance" shall mean a dwelling unit which
is identical, or substantially similar, to another in any three (3) of the
following characteristics with respect to the front facade:
      1.   Roof type (gable, hip, mansard, gambrel, flat or combination).
Mixtures of roof types and design are sufficient to render dwelling units
dissimilar.
      2.   Roof height or pitch shall be significantly different.
      3.   Approximate dimensions (height and length) of the front wall closest
to the front lot line.
      4.   Shape of the front elevation silhouette.
      5.   Relative locations, types and sizes of windows in the front
elevation. The addition or subtractions of muntin bars, small gable or hip
projections above windows, and window dormers are not sufficient to make
adjacent structures dissimilar.
      6.   Relative location, design and dimensions of garage door, if included
on the front elevation.
      7.   Type and color of front facade materials (e.g., brick veneer, lapped
horizontal siding, half timber, board and batten, shakes, etc.). Changes in
materials must occur throughout the front facade or elevation for a minimum of
one story in height. Color change shall be made by significant changes in
shades of color.
   (B)   Distinguishing Characteristics, Side And Rear Facades On Corner Lots,
And Rear Facades Fronting A Public Right-Of-Way: For the purpose of this
subsection, the term "similar in appearance" shall mean a dwelling which is
identical, or substantially similar, to another type and color of side and rear
facade (e.g., brick veneer, lapped horizontal siding, half timber, board and
batten, shakes, etc.). Changes in materials must occur throughout the entire
facade or elevation for a minimum of one story in height. Color change shall be
made by significant changes in shades of color.
   (C)   Housing Styles: Housing style is in and of itself a significant enough
characteristic to constitute dissimilarity with respect to the subject lot and
the similarity standards delineated in subsections (A) and (B) of this section
do not apply. Housing styles shall consist of the following: ranch, bi- level,
tri-level, one and one-half story, and two-story.
   (D)   Model Homes: Elevation designs must be provided for each type of
dwelling. For model designs, a minimum of three (3) alternate elevations for
each design shall be provided to the Village and to prospective customers.
(Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-7-4: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT; APPEALS:
   (A)   Rules: The Village Administrator, or his/her designee, is authorized
to make rules regarding the interpretation of the provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   Determination: The Code Enforcement Officer shall make the initial
determination as to similarity in appearance and shall not issue a building
permit for any dwelling unit which violates the provisions of this chapter. If
a permit is denied, written reasons shall be provided detailing why the
proposed dwelling unit is similar in appearance to another dwelling unit.
   (C)   Appeal: A decision by the Code Enforcement Officer denying a permit
may be appealed in writing to the Building and Planning Committee of the
Village Board, or such other committee as authorized thereby.
   (D)   Variations: The Board of Trustees reserves the right to waive the
provisions of this chapter by motion approved at a Board meeting.
   (E)   Applicability: The provisions of this chapter apply only to the
issuance of building permits for a newly constructed dwelling unit and not to
remodeling or reconstruction. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
CHAPTER 8
PLAN REVIEW FEES
SECTION:
4-8-1: Fees And Costs For Plan And Application Review
4-8-2: Fees For Outside Consultants; Notice
4-8-3: Fees For Staff Review
4-8-4: Final Action; Payment Of Fees
4-8-1: FEES AND COSTS FOR PLAN AND APPLICATION REVIEW:
In addition to any other fees provided for in this Code, the Village
Administrator, Department Heads, the Planning Commission and the Chairmen of
committees of the Village Board, along with other Municipal officials who may
be authorized from time to time to do so, with prior written notice to the
Administrator, may retain outside consultants with established expertise in
disciplines necessary to evaluate applications for annexation, zoning,
subdivision and construction to assist the officials of the Village, its
committees and the Corporate Authorities in processing applications for
Municipal action or permission. For purposes of this chapter, the terms
"necessary or desirable" do not mean only such measures as are absolutely and
indispensably necessary, but include all appropriate means which are conducive
or adaptable to the end to be accomplished and which, in the judgment of the
authorized official, will most advantageously permit the Municipality to act
upon the application or request. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-8-2: FEES FOR OUTSIDE CONSULTANTS; NOTICE:
The Village shall disclose to the applicant or requesting party that it is
utilizing such consulting services, and that party must pay within thirty (30)
days after the submission of an invoice from the consultant for the services
provided. The services provided shall be reasonable and customary, and the
invoices shall be itemized and shall be within a range generally chargeable by
the consultants in performing similar services. It shall not be a defense to
the payment of such invoices that the applicant could obtain such consultant
services at a lower cost, so long as the fees charged by the Village's
consultants are within the range typically charged for similar services by
outside consultants to municipalities within the Chicago metropolitan area. The
intention of the Corporate Authorities is to utilize experienced and competent
consultants to fairly assess the material they are asked to review with
adequate time to provide excellent reports to Village officials, who will then
be able to reach fair decisions without prejudice or uncertainty. (Ord. O-11-
17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-8-3: FEES FOR STAFF REVIEW:
In addition to establishing a system for the invoicing of consultants' fees,
the Village may charge the reasonable cost for its own employees to process,
analyze and report upon the application or request. The Village Administrator
may, from time to time, establish, subject to approval of the Village Board,
standardized fees for application, analysis or review processes. Where no
standard fee has been established, the provisions of section
4-8-1 of this chapter shall apply. Notice of standard fees shall be provided to
any applicant as part of the application information. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-
2017)
4-8-4: FINAL ACTION; PAYMENT OF FEES:
Final action on any application may be delayed until any amount due and payable
has been paid. The Village may require the posting of an irrevocable letter of
credit to guarantee that payments will be promptly made. The Municipality may
require a certified check or the posting of an irrevocable letter of credit to
guarantee fees and consultant costs already incurred, but not paid, at the time
the application or permit is acted upon. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
CHAPTER 9
SWIMMING POOLS
SECTION:
4-9-1: Requirements
4-9-2: Penalties
4-9-1: REQUIREMENTS:
All swimming pools having a capable depth of two feet (2') or more shall
conform to the requirements and standards under the International Building Code
as adopted by the Village. Included in those requirements are the following:
   (A)   A swimming pool or appurtenances thereto shall not be constructed,
installed, enlarged or altered until construction documents have been submitted
and a permit has been obtained from the Code Enforcement Officer.
   (B)   At least one means of egress shall be provided from private pools.
   (C)   Outdoor private swimming pools shall be provided with a barrier which
shall comply with the following:
      1.   The top of the barrier shall be at least forty eight inches (48")
above finished ground level. Where the tip of the pool structure is above
finished ground level, such as an aboveground pool, the barrier shall be at
finished ground level, such as the pool structure, or shall be mounted on top
of the pool structure. Openings in the barrier shall not allow passage of a
four inch (4") diameter sphere.
      2.   Gates shall be equipped with self-closing and self-latching devices
designed to keep, and capable of keeping, such gate securely closed at all
times when not in actual use. Deck and stair gates should be installed at the
bottom of the stairs and should swing out away from the pool. However, if
design restrictions prevent the installation of the gate as described above,
and the gate must be installed at the top of the stairs, that gate should swing
in order to prevent potential stair accidents.
      3.   Where an aboveground pool structure is used as the barrier or where
the barrier is mounted on top of the pool structure and the means of access is
a ladder or steps, the ladder or steps shall be capable of being secured,
locked or removed to prevent access, or the ladder or steps shall be surrounded
by a barrier that meets International Residential Code requirements.
   (D)   All outdoor swimming pools are considered accessory uses and shall
meet minimum yard requirements, however, no portion of any private swimming
pool or appurtenant equipment (including pumps, filters, and heaters) shall be
located at a distance less than five feet (5') from any side or rear property
line and may not be placed in any front yard. Corner lots will be considered as
having two (2) front yards.
   (E)   All electrical devices used in conjunction with or connected to all
pools must be grounded and protected by approved ground fault interrupt
circuits.
   (F)   An approved pool cover shall be installed during those periods when
use of the pool is discontinued. Unused pools on residential premises not
occupied or dwelt in for a period of thirty (30) days or more shall be
completely drained or equipped with an approved pool cover. Abandoned pools, as
determined by the Code Enforcement Officer, shall be removed or filled to the
grade of adjacent land. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-9-2: PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall
be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
CHAPTER 10
CARBON MONOXIDE ALARM DETECTORS
SECTION:
4-10-1: Definitions
4-10-2: Carbon Monoxide Detector
4-10-3: Prohibitions
4-10-4: Exemptions
4-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them for purposes of
this chapter:
APPROVED CARBON MONOXIDE ALARM: A carbon monoxide alarm that complies with all
the requirements of the rules and regulations of the Illinois State Fire
Marshal, bears the label of a nationally recognized testing laboratory, and
complies with the most recent standards of the Underwriters Laboratories or the
Canadian Standard Association.
DWELLING UNIT: A room or suite of rooms used for human habitation, and includes
a single-family residence as well as each living unit of a multi-family
residence and each living unit in a mixed use building. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-
2017)
4-10-2: CARBON MONOXIDE DETECTOR:
   (A)   Every dwelling unit shall be equipped with at least one approved
carbon monoxide alarm in an operating condition within fifteen feet (15') of
every room used for sleeping purposes. The carbon monoxide alarm may be
combined with smoke detecting devices provided that the combined unit is an
approved carbon monoxide alarm and provided that the combined unit emits a
warning in a manner that clearly differentiates the hazard.
   (B)   Every structure that contains more than one dwelling unit shall
contain at least one approved carbon monoxide alarm in operating condition
within fifteen feet (15') of every room used for sleeping purposes.
   (C)   It is the responsibility of the owner of a structure to supply and
install all required carbon monoxide alarms. It is the responsibility of a
tenant to test and to provide general maintenance for the carbon monoxide
alarms within the tenant's dwelling unit or rooming unit, and to notify the
owner or the authorized agent of the owner in writing of any deficiencies that
the tenant cannot correct. The owner is responsible for providing one tenant
per dwelling unit with written information regarding carbon monoxide alarm
testing and maintenance.
   (D)   The tenant is responsible for replacement of any required batteries in
the carbon monoxide alarms in the tenant's dwelling unit, except that the owner
shall ensure that the batteries are in operating condition at the time the
tenant takes possession of the dwelling unit. The tenant shall provide the
owner or the authorized agent of the owner with access to the dwelling unit to
correct any deficiencies in the carbon monoxide alarm that have been reported
in writing to the owner or the authorized agent of the owner.
   (E)   The carbon monoxide alarms required under this chapter may be either
battery powered, plug in with battery backup, or wired into the structure's AC
power line with secondary battery backup. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-10-3: PROHIBITIONS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to install or maintain a
carbon monoxide alarm as required by this chapter.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with, remove, destroy or
disconnect any installed carbon monoxide alarm.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to remove batteries from an
installed carbon monoxide alarm except for the purpose of contemporaneously
replacing such batteries. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-10-4: EXEMPTIONS:
The following residential units shall not require carbon monoxide detectors:
   (A)   A residential unit in a building that: 1) does not rely on combustion
of fossil fuel for heat, ventilation, or hot water; 2) is not connected in any
way to a garage; and 3) is not sufficiently close to any ventilated source of
carbon monoxide, as determined by the Building Commissioner, to receive carbon
monoxide from that source.
   (B)   A residential unit that is not sufficiently close to any source of
carbon monoxide so as to be at risk of receiving carbon monoxide from that
source, as determined by the Building Commissioner. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-
2017)
CHAPTER 11
ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF BUILDING CODE VIOLATIONS
SECTION:
4-11-1: Code Hearing Unit Established
4-11-2: Hearing Officer; Appointment
4-11-3: Hearing Officer; Duties And Powers
4-11-4: Institution Of Administrative Proceedings
4-11-5: Representation
4-11-6: Default
4-11-7: Adjudication By Mail
4-11-8: Continuances
4-11-9: Rules And Regulations
4-11-10: Subpoenas
4-11-11: Defenses
4-11-12: Findings, Decision, And Order
4-11-13: Review Under Administrative Review Law
4-11-14: Judgment On Findings, Decision, And Order
4-11-15: Sanctions Applicable To Owner And Property
4-11-1: CODE HEARING UNIT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby created a Code Hearing Unit which shall be known as the
"Village of Grant Park Building Code Hearing Unit". The Village of Grant Park
Building Code Hearing Unit is established to provide a fair and efficient
method of enforcing any Municipal law, Housing or Building Code or zoning
ordinance that establishes construction or other health and safety standards of
the Village of Grant Park or any ordinance that requires, after notice, the
cutting of weeds, the removal of garbage and debris, the removal of inoperable
motor vehicles, or the abatement of nuisances from private property
(collectively "Building Code"). The Village of Grant Park reserves the right to
employ all other means and methods available under the law to enforce its
Building Code, including direct application to the courts. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-
20-2017)
4-11-2: HEARING OFFICER; APPOINTMENT:
The Hearing Officer appointed to preside over the administrative adjudication
of ordinance violations pursuant to title 1, chapter 15, "Administrative
Adjudication", of this Code for the Village of Grant Park shall be the Hearing
Officer and shall preside over the adjudication of Building Code violations
under this chapter. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-11-3: HEARING OFFICER; DUTIES AND POWERS:
A Hearing Officer shall have the following duties and powers under this
chapter:
   (A)   All duties set forth by State Statute including:
      1.   Preside at an administrative hearing called to determine whether or
not a Building Code violation exists;
      2.   Hear testimony and accept evidence from all interested parties
relevant to the existence of a Building Code violation;
      3.   Preserve and authenticate the transcript and record of the hearing
and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing;
      4.   Issue and sign a written finding, decision, and order stating
whether a Building Code violation exists; and
      5.   Imposing penalties consistent with applicable Code provisions.
   (B)   Hold preliminary conferences for the settlement or simplification of
issues.
   (C)   Administer oaths and affirmations.
   (D)   Rule upon motions, objections, and the admissibility of evidence.
   (E)   Issue subpoenas for the attendance of witnesses or the production of
documents or other tangible items.
   (F)   Exercise all powers and duties necessary and proper to the
administration of fair and impartial hearing under this chapter. (Ord. O-11-17-
1, 11-20-2017)
4-11-4: INSTITUTION OF ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEEDINGS:
The following shall govern the commencement of administrative adjudication
proceedings under this chapter:
   (A)   When the Director of Building and Zoning or other individual
authorized to issue a Building Code violation finds a Building Code violation
to exist, he or she shall note the violation on a multiple copy violation
notice and report form that indicates: 1) the name and address of the owner of
the property; 2) the type and nature of the violation; 3) the date and time the
violation was observed; 4) the names of witnesses to the violation; and 5) the
address of the property where the violation is observed.
   (B)   The violation report form shall be forwarded to the Village of Grant
Park Building Code Hearing Unit where a docket number shall be stamped on all
copies of the report and a hearing date shall be noted in the blank spaces
provided for that purpose on the form. The hearing date shall not be less than
thirty (30) nor more than forty (40) days after the violation is reported.
   (C)   One copy of the violation report shall be maintained in the files of
the Village of Grant Park Building Code Hearing Unit and shall become a part of
the record. One copy of the report shall be returned to the individual
representing the Municipality so that he/she may prepare evidence of the Code
violation for presentation at the hearing. Finally, one copy of the report form
shall be served by first class mail to the owner of the structure, along with a
summons commanding the owner to appear at the hearing. If the name of the owner
of the structure cannot be ascertained or if service on the owner cannot be
made by mail, service may be made on the owner by posting or nailing a copy of
the violation report form on the front door of the structure where the
violation is found, not less than twenty (20) days before the hearing is
scheduled. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-11-5: REPRESENTATION:
The Village's case may be presented by an attorney or by any other Municipal
employee that is not an employee of the Village of Grant Park Building Code
Hearing Unit. The case for the owner may be presented by the owner, his/her
attorney, or any other agent or representative of the owner. (Ord. O-11-17-1,
11-20-2017)
4-11-6: DEFAULT:
In the event an owner or his/her attorney fails to appear at a hearing, the
Hearing Officer shall find the owner in default and proceed with the hearing
and accept evidence relevant to the existence of a Building Code violation.
(Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-11-7: ADJUDICATION BY MAIL:
An owner may elect to contest a violation without personally appearing at the
hearing. To do so, the owner must send a letter to the Village of Grant Park
Building Code Hearing Unit identifying his/her case, the date of the hearing,
his/her desire to proceed in absentia, and a short argument as to why a finding
of nonliability for the Building Code violation is appropriate. To be
considered, the letter must be received by the Village of Grant Park Building
Code Hearing Unit no later than five (5) days before the hearing date. A
notarized affidavit shall be submitted with the letter setting forth the facts
that support the owner's defense. The owner may also include any other evidence
which he/she believes supports a finding of nonliability. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-
20-2017)
4-11-8: CONTINUANCES:
No continuances shall be authorized by the Hearing Officer unless it is
absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the owner. Lack of preparation
shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance authorized by the
Hearing Officer shall not exceed twenty five (25) days. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-
2017)
4-11-9: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
Parties shall be provided with an opportunity to present witnesses, evidence
and to cross examine other witnesses. The formal and technical rules of
evidence shall not apply at the hearings authorized by this chapter. Provided,
however, evidence, including hearsay, shall only be admitted if it is of the
type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent person in the conduct of their
affairs. Any other rules and regulations promulgated for the conduct of
administrative hearings shall be developed by the Hearing Officer and shall be
published and kept on file in the Office of the Village Clerk where they shall
be available to the public for inspection and copying during normal business
hours. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-11-10: SUBPOENAS:
The Hearing Officer may, at the request of either party, issue a subpoena
compelling the appearance of a witness to testify or for the production of
documents or other tangible items. Requests shall be made in writing to the
Village of Grant Park Building Code Hearing Unit. No subpoena issued pursuant
to this chapter shall be valid unless signed by the Hearing Officer. No
subpoena shall be issued by a Hearing Officer unless it is relevant to the
contested issues in the case. All subpoenas issued shall identify: a) the
person or entity to which it is directed; b) the documents or other items to be
produced; c) the person that is to appear; d) the date and time for the
witness' appearance or by which the production is to be made; and e) the
location at which the witness is to appear or at which the production is to be
made. No subpoenas issued under this chapter shall require the appearance of a
witness, or the production of documents or other tangible items, sooner than
seven (7) days after service of the subpoena. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-11-11: DEFENSES:
It shall be a defense to a Building Code violation charged under this chapter
if the owner, his attorney, or other agent or representative proves to the
Hearing Officer's satisfaction that:
   (A)   The Building Code violation alleged in the notice does not in fact
exist, or at the time of the hearing the Building Code violation has been
remedied or removed;
   (B)   The Building Code violation has been caused by the current property
occupants and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the owner to maintain the
dwelling free of such Building Code violations, the current occupants continue
to cause the Building Code violations; or
   (C)   An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the owner
or his agent to all or a part of the dwelling for the purpose of correcting the
Building Code violation. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-11-12: FINDINGS, DECISION, AND ORDER:
At the conclusion of the hearing, the Hearing Officer shall make a
determination based on the evidence presented at the hearing as to whether or
not a Building Code violation exists. The determination shall be in writing and
shall be designated as findings, decision, and order. The findings, decision,
and order shall include: a) the Hearing Officer's findings of fact; b) a
decision of whether or not a Building Code violation exists based upon the
findings of fact; c) an order that requires the owner to correct the violation
or dismisses the case if a violation is not proved; and d) a monetary sanction.
A monetary sanction for a violation under this chapter shall not exceed seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). A copy of the findings, decision, and order
shall be served on the owner within five (5) days after it is issued. Service
shall be in the same manner that the report form and summons are served under
section
4-11-4 of this chapter. Monies received by the Village as payment for any
monetary sanction may be used for general corporate purposes. (Ord. O-11-17-1,
11-20-2017)
4-11-13: REVIEW UNDER ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW LAW:
The findings, decision, and order of the Hearing Officer shall be subject to
review in the Circuit Court of Kankakee County. The provisions of the
Administrative Review Law, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto, shall apply
to and govern every action for the judicial review of the findings, decision
and order of a Hearing Officer under this chapter. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-11-14: JUDGMENT ON FINDINGS, DECISION, AND ORDER:
The owner shall pay the penalty assessed no later than five (5) business days
after the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures.
All penalties assessed shall be a debt due and owing the Village and may be
collected in accordance with the law. Penalties not paid in a timely manner
shall accrue interest in the amount of five percent (5%) per annum. After
expiration of the period within which judicial review under the Administrative
Review Law may be sought for a final determination of the Building Code
violation, the Village may commence a proceeding in the Circuit Court of
Kankakee County for the purposes of obtaining a judgment on the findings,
decision, and order. (Ord. O-11-17-1, 11-20-2017)
4-11-15: SANCTIONS APPLICABLE TO OWNER AND PROPERTY:
The order to correct a Building Code violation and the sanctions imposed by the
Village as a result of a finding of a Building Code violation under this
chapter shall attach to the property as well as to the owner of the property,
so that a finding of a Building Code violation against one owner cannot be
avoided by conveying or transferring the property to another owner. Any
subsequent transferee or owner of property takes title subject to the findings,
decision and order of the Hearing Officer under this chapter. (Ord. O-11-17-1,
11-20-2017)
