ARTICLE I.
IN GENERAL
6-1-1-1: NUISANCES DECLARED UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to wilfully
or negligently create, erect, maintain or permit a nuisance to exist anywhere
within the village. (1975 Code)
6-1-1-2: NUISANCE DEFINED, GENERALLY:
Any thing, act, omission, occupation or condition which shall exist or continue
for such length of time as to:
   (A)   Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the health, safety, peace or
welfare of the public; or
   (B)   In any way render the public insecure of life or property; or
   (C)   Greatly offend the public morals or decency; or
   (D)   Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or render
dangerous for passage any street, sidewalk, alley, navigable body or other
public way or place;
is hereby declared a nuisance. (1975 Code)
6-1-1-3: NUISANCES NOT ENUMERATED HEREIN:
Any nuisance declared by statute, this chapter or other provisions of this code
or ordinances of the village shall be enforceable under the provisions of this
chapter as if enumerated specifically herein. (1975 Code)
6-1-1-4: ENUMERATION NOT EXCLUSIVE:
Nuisances enumerated in this chapter shall not be deemed exclusive, but are in
addition to and to be construed in conjunction with any other nuisances
enumerated in statutes or other provisions of this code or ordinances of the
village. (1975 Code)
6-1-1-5: DUTY OF VILLAGE OFFICER TO INVESTIGATE; POWER OF ENTRY:
   (A)   For the purpose of discovering nuisances, it shall be the duty of
police, fire, health and building officers and inspectors to investigate,
confirm and report any nuisances coming to their attention.
   (B)   In order to investigate, confirm and report nuisances, said officers
and inspectors shall, upon proper identification, be permitted, at any
reasonable hour and in a reasonable manner, to visit and enter into or upon any
premises or property within the Village to make an examination thereof, if they
shall have reasonable grounds to believe that a nuisance exists.
6-1-1-6: NOTICE TO PROPER OFFICIALS:
Whenever any nuisance shall be reported to or investigated and determined by
the police, fire, health or building officers or inspectors, notice shall be
given to the owner or person in control of the property or premises involved,
and to the appropriate Village officials whose functions include the abatement
of such nuisances.
ARTICLE II.   CERTAIN NUISANCES DECLARED
6-1-2-1: FOUL ODORS, FILTH:
It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a danger to the health, safety,
welfare, peace and comfort of the Village and its residents for any person:
   (A)   Businesses: To conduct any business or to use any premises so as to
create an offensive or foul odor which taints the air and renders it nauseous
to persons in the vicinity; or
   (B)   Animals: To keep or maintain any animals in an unclean or filthy
manner or surroundings, or to keep or maintain any animals from which emit any
particularly foul or offensive odors; or
   (C)   Animal Carcasses: To cause or permit to be collected or to remain upon
any premises or place any animal carcass of any offal, filth, excretion or
other noisome or noxious animal matter of any kind which is, or is likely to
become, putrid, foul or offensive; or
   (D)   Vegetable Matter: To cause or permit to be collected or to remain upon
any premises or place any slop or other vegetable matter of any kind which is,
or is likely to become, putrid, foul or offensive; or
   (E)   Cellars, Vaults, Privies: To cause or permit any cellar, vault,
cistern, drain, privy, yard or other premises whatsoever to become, from any
cause, foul or offensive or injurious to the public health; or (1975 Code)
   (F)   Stagnant Water: Any lot of ground or premises within the Village upon
which stagnant water may be standing so as to become or is likely to become
foul, putrid or offensive or detrimental to the health and comfort of any
person or family residing in the Village, or in the vicinity of such ground or
premises, is hereby declared a nuisance. Any owner or agent of such lot of
ground, or any person in possession or control of such lot or premises who
shall fail or neglect to abate such nuisance, after notice as specified in
Section
 6-1-3-1 hereof, shall be deemed guilty of having a nuisance under the terms of
this Chapter and subject to penalty. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 6.2.4)
   (G)   Stables and Pigsties: To locate or maintain, or permit to exist or
remain, anywhere within the Village any stable or pigsty; or
   (H)   Foul or Noxious Substances: To use, deposit or keep any property,
substance or thing emitting or causing any foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous
or noxious odor, effluvia or stench particularly repulsive to the physical
senses and which annoys, discomforts or endangers the welfare, health or safety
of any person.
6-1-2-2: RUBBISH, DRY GRASS:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and health and a nuisance
for any person to cause or permit:
   (A)   Rubbish, Rags: The deposit or accumulation of any refuse, oily rags,
rubbish or other materials or substances of any kind, so as to constitute a
fire hazard; or
   (B)   Dry Grass, Vegetation: The deposit, accumulation, existence or growth
upon any property of any dry or dead weeds, grass, vegetation or other like
substances of any kind, so as to constitute a fire hazard.
6-1-2-3: WEEDS:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and health and a nuisance
for any person to cause or permit:
   (A)   Jimson, Burdock: Any weeds, such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle,
cocklebur, or other weeds of a like kind, to grow in any lot or tract of land
in the Village.
   (B)   Height: Any weeds, grass or plants other than trees, buses, flowers,
vegetables or other ornamental plants to grow to a height exceeding eight
inches (8") anywhere in the Village.
   (C)   Barberry Bushes: Growth of the bush of the tall, common or European
Barberry, further known as Berberis Vulgaris or its horticultural varieties,
within the Village.
6-1-2-4: EXPLOSIVES:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person to cause or permit the deposit, accumulation, storage or presence,
within one hundred (100) yards of any building occupied as a residence or
business of any powder magazine, nitroglycerine, dynamite or other explosive
substance of any kind.
6-1-2-5: UNSAFE BUILDINGS:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person to cause or permit the existence of any unsafe, dilapidated or otherwise
insecure building, wall, stack, chimney, cornice, sign, awning or other like
structure of any kind which, from manner of construction, age, condition or
other circumstances, is or may become a menace to the safety of persons or
property.
The term "unsafe building" as used herein is hereby defined to mean and include
a) any building, shed, fence or other man-made structure which is dangerous to
the public health because of its construction or condition, or which may cause
or aid in the spread of disease or cause injury to the health of the occupants
of it or of neighboring structures; b) any building, shed, fence or other man-
made structure which, because of faulty construction, age, lack of proper
repair or any other cause, is especially liable to fire, and constitutes or
creates a fire hazard; c) any building, shed, fence or other man-made structure
which, by reason of faulty construction, age, lack of proper repair or any
other cause, is liable to cause injury or damage by collapsing or by a collapse
or fall of any part of such a structure; d) any building, shed, fence or other
man-made structure which, because of its condition or because of lack of doors
or windows is available to and frequented by malefactors or disorderly persons
who are not lawful occupants of such structure.
If any building shall be found in a dangerous and unsafe condition, the
President or any official or employee designated by the Village Board shall
notify, in writing, the owner or owners thereof, directing said owner or owners
to put such building in a safe condition or to demolish it. Where, upon
diligent search, the identity or whereabouts of the owner or owners of any such
building shall not be ascertainable, such notice shall be mailed to the person
or persons in whose name such real estate was last assessed.
If, after fifteen (15) days subsequent to the giving of such notice, said owner
or owners fail to put such building in a safe condition or to demolish it, the
President or any official or employee designated by the Village Board shall so
notify the Village Board requesting the Board to direct the Village Attorney to
apply on behalf of the Village to the Circuit Court of Kankakee County for an
order authorizing the Village to demolish or repair, or to cause the demolition
or repair of said building.
The cost of such demolition or repair shall be recoverable from the owner or
owners of such real estate, and shall be a lien thereon as provided in 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31-1, as amended.
6-1-2-6: ABANDONED REFRIGERATORS:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person to cause or permit the existence or storage in any place accessible to
children of any abandoned or discarded refrigerator, icebox, ice chest, deep
freeze or other airtight appliance or container of any kind, of a capacity of
one and one-half (11/2) cubic feet or more, from which the lids, doors or other
covers have not been removed or which cannot easily be opened by a child, by
means of pushing only, from the inside thereof.
6-1-2-7: DUST, CINDERS:
   (A)   It is hereby declared a menace to the public health and a nuisance for
any person to cause or permit any operations that cause or permit any dirt,
sand, gravel, cinders, ashes, earth or other similar materials to be hauled,
moved, rolled, compacted, scraped, dragged or otherwise disturbed so as to
cause or permit dust to be raised, blown or stirred through the operation of
machinery or otherwise to the detriment of any person or property.
   (B)   Every person engaged in hauling of any sand, dirt, cinders, ashes,
earth or other similar materials or substances, or engaged in the moving,
rolling, compacting, scraping, dragging or other disturbance of soil and the
like, shall make adequate provision as often as is required to arrest and
prevent such dust through the use of salts, oil, chemicals and other materials
used and recommended for retarding or eliminating such dust, subject to the
supervision and approval of the Director of Public Works.
6-1-2-8: SCAFFOLDING, LADDERS:
It is hereby declared a menace to the public safety and a nuisance for any
person:
   (A)   To erect or use, or to cause or permit to be erected or used, any
insecure or unsafe scaffold or ladder whereby the safety of persons working
thereon or passing thereunder may in any way be endangered.
   (B)   To place or leave, or to cause or permit to be placed or left, any
tools or articles on any such scaffold or ladder in such manner that the same
may fall into any street, sidewalk or other public way, whereby the safety of
persons passing thereunder may in any way be endangered. (1975 Code)
6-1-2-9: ANIMALS:
   (A)   Prohibited: No person shall cause to be kept or keep, within the
limits of the Village, and hold or raise the same, any animal other than what
is normally recognized as a house pet, nor shall any livestock, fowl, farm
animals or wild creatures be kept for any time within the Village. (R.O. 1974,
Sec. 6.2.2)
   (B)   Cattle Pens, Stock Yards: Any cattle pens, stock yards, chutes and
other places within the Village used for shipping, loading or unloading cattle,
sheep or hogs, which may be detrimental or obnoxious to the health and comfort
of persons residing or doing business in the neighborhood of the same, by
reason of the filthy condition thereof, are hereby declared to be a nuisance,
and any person having charge or control of such a place shall be held guilty of
a nuisance under the terms of this Chapter and will be subject to the fines of
this Chapter. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 6.2.6)
   (C)   Dead Animals: If any person shall allow any pet belonging to him, or
in his charge, coming to its death by disease or otherwise, to lie in or upon
any street, avenue, alley, sidewalk or other ground, public or private, in the
Village, he shall be subject to penalty hereunder for maintaining a nuisance.
(R.O. 1974, Sec. 6.2.7)
6-1-2-10: OBSTRUCT, INJURE NATURAL DRAINAGE:
Any person who shall obstruct, fill up or change the natural drainage in the
Village, without first obtaining the consent of the Board of Trustees, shall be
liable to a penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Each
day that such person shall continue obstruction or change after being notified
by the Street Commissioner of the Village, or any other officer of the Village,
to discontinue such obstruction or change shall result in a five hundred dollar
($500.00) fee and shall be deemed to be a separate offense under the law.
(Ord., 9-19-94)
6-1-2-11: FENCE, GATE OBSTRUCTING PUBLIC TRAVEL:
Any gate found open and extended upon any sidewalk or into any street, avenue
or alley so as to interfere with the public travel, or be dangerous to persons
or property, and any fence that is put upon any property that extends to a
height that makes it impossible for any person walking or driving to see into
the walkway or street upon which persons will travel, and also any shrubbery or
live hedge type growth that does the same, or in both cases above if the
construction or growth is deemed to be dangerous to persons or property, will
not be allowed. All gates opening upon any public place in the sidewalk shall
be so constructed and hung that no part of such gate shall swing over, upon or
above any part of the sidewalk, unless the same shall be so constructed and
hung as to be self-shutting. Any person being the owner or agent of such
construction or gate or growth will remove the same or make it otherwise safe
according to this Section or such person shall be deemed guilty of maintaining
a nuisance and subject to the fines under the terms of this Chapter. (R.O.
1974, Sec. 6.2.8; amd. R.O. 1974, Sec. 13.1.8)
6-1-2-12: SANITARY OR WASTE SEWER CONNECTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or institution, public
or private, to connect or cause to be connected, any drain carrying, or to
carry, any toilet, sink, basement, septic tank, cesspool, industrial waste or
any fixture or device discharging polluting substances, to any open ditch,
drain, or drainage structure installed solely for street or highway drainage
purposes in the Village of Grant Park or to connect same into the existing
storm or existing field tile system within the Municipal boundary.
Any person, firm, or corporation violating this ordinance shall be fined not
less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed for each and every day during which a
violation continues or exists. (Ord., 9-19-1994)
 
ARTICLE III.   ABATEMENT
6-1-3-1: NOTICE TO ABATE NUISANCE:
   (A)   Whenever any health or building official or inspector, or any police
or fire officer, determines that a nuisance exists on any private property or
premises, except as otherwise provided herein, the proper village official
shall cause a written notice to be served personally upon the owner or, if the
owner cannot be found, upon the occupant or person in control of the property
or premises who is causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance, and shall
cause a copy of said notice to be conspicuously posted within or upon such
property or premises.
   (B)   Such notice shall fairly appraise such person of the nature of the
nuisance, his duty to abate or remove the nuisance within the time provided
therein, the penalty for failure to abate the same, and shall state that, if
said nuisance is abated by the village, liability for necessary expenses so
incurred shall accrue as provided for in section
6-1-3-6 of this chapter. (1975 Code)
6-1-3-2: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCES; VILLAGE TO ABATE; TIME LIMITS:
It is hereby declared the duty of any person determined to have created,
caused, erected, maintained or permitted a nuisance to exist within the village
to discontinue and abate such nuisance within forty eight (48) hours or such
other time period as may be specified therein, from the time he receives
written notice thereof. (1975 Code)
6-1-3-3: FAILURE TO ABATE, SEPARATE AND RECURRING OFFENSE:
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person to neglect,
refuse or otherwise fail to remove or abate any nuisance after expiration of
the forty eight (48) hour or other specified time period provided by notice
thereof; and each twenty four (24) hours, or fraction thereof, during which
such nuisance continues or exists shall be deemed a separate offense. (1975
Code)
6-1-3-4: FAILURE TO ABATE; ABATEMENT BY VILLAGE:
Whenever any nuisance is not abated by the owner, lessee or person in control
of premises or property affected within the time provided by notice, the proper
village officer shall cause the abatement or removal of such nuisance. (1975
Code)
6-1-3-5: SUMMARY ABATEMENT BY VILLAGE WHEN EMERGENCY OR ON PUBLIC PROPERTY:
Whenever any nuisance: a) constitutes or is deemed to be an imminent or
immediate danger to public health or safety, or b) exists on public property,
the proper village officer shall cause such nuisance to be summarily and
immediately abated and removed, regardless of any forty eight (48) hour or
other time period specified by notice to the person responsible therefor;
provided, however, that in situation a) above, such officer shall have first
applied for and obtained the written permission of the president for such
summary abatement. (1975 Code)
6-1-3-6: COSTS OF ABATEMENT; DEBT OF OWNER:
   (A)   Any costs or expenses of abatement reasonably incurred by the village
pursuant to the provisions of sections
6-1-3-4 and
6-1-3-5 of this chapter shall be deemed a debt to the village by the owner,
lessee or person in control of premises upon which such nuisance existed;
provided, that where specifically provided in this code or by statute, such
costs and expenses shall become a lien upon the real estate or personal
property affected, superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax
liens.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of the village attorney to enforce by civil
action any and all such debts or liens as provided in subsection (A) of this
section. (1975 Code)
 
ARTICLE IV.   CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTIES
6-1-4-1: VIOLATION:
This code shall be amended to provide the following:
   (A)   Any certain property within the village of Grant Park which becomes a
chronic nuisance property is in violation of this article and is subject to its
remedies.
   (B)   Any person in charge who permits property under his or her ownership
or control to be a public nuisance property shall be in violation of this
article and subject to its remedies. (Ord. 02-04-15-2, 4-15-2002)
6-1-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTY: Property upon which three (3) or more of the
behaviors listed below have occurred during any sixty (60) day period, as a
result of any three (3) separate factual events that have been independently
investigated by any law enforcement agency:
   (A)   Disorderly conduct as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/26-
1.
   (B)   Unlawful use of weapons as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/24-01 et seq.
   (C)   Mob action as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/25-1.
   (D)   Discharge of a firearm as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
24-1.2 and 5/24-1.5.
   (E)   Gambling as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-1.
   (F)   Possession, manufacture or delivery of controlled substances as
defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/401 et seq.
   (G)   Assault or battery or any related offense as defined in 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/12-1 et seq.
   (H)   Sexual abuse or related offenses as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/12-15 et seq.
   (I)   Public indecency as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-9.
   (J)   Prostitution as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-14 et
seq.
   (K)   Criminal damage to property as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/21-1 et seq.
   (L)   Possession, cultivation, manufacture or delivery of cannabis as
defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/2 et seq.
   (M)   Illegal consumption or possession of alcohol as defined in 235
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1 et seq.
CONTROL: The ability to regulate, restrain, dominate, counteract or govern
conduct that occurs on that property.
OWNER: Any person, agent, firm or corporation having any legal or equitable
interest in the property. Owner includes, but it is not limited to: a) a
mortgagee in possession in whom is vested: 1) all or part of the legal title to
the property; or 2) all or part of the beneficial ownership and the right to
the present use and enjoyment of the premises; or b) an occupant who can
control what occurs on the property.
PERMIT: To suffer, allow, consent to, acquiesce by failure to prevent, or
expressly ascent or agree to the doing of an act.
PERSON: Any natural person, association, partnership or corporation capable of
owning or using property in the village of Grant Park.
PERSON IN CHARGE: Any person in actual or constructive possession of a
property, including, but not limited to, an owner, occupant of property under
his or her domain, ownership or control.
PROPERTY: Any real property, including land in that which is affixed,
incidental or pertinent to land, including, but not limited to, any premises,
room, house, building, or structure or any separate part or portion thereof,
whether permitted or not. (Ord. 02-04-15-2, 4-15-2002)
6-1-4-3: REMEDY:
   (A)   In the event a court determines property to be a chronic nuisance
property, the court may order that the property be closed and secured against
all use and occupancy for a period of not less than thirty (30) days, but not
more than one hundred eighty (180) days, or the court may employ any other
remedy deemed by it to be appropriate to abate the nuisance.
   (B)   In addition to the remedy provided in subsection (A) of this section,
the court may impose upon the owner of the property a civil penalty in the
amount of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day, payable to the village
of Grant Park, for each day the owner had actual knowledge that the property
was a public nuisance property and permitted the property to remain public
nuisance property.
   (C)   In determining what remedy or remedies shall employ, the court may
consider evidence of other conduct which has occurred on the property,
including, but not limited to:
      1.   The disturbance of neighbors.
      2.   The recurrence of loud and obnoxious noises.
      3.   Repeated consumption of alcohol in public. (Ord. 02-04-15-2, 4-15-
2002)
6-1-4-4: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE:
The village attorney of the village of Grant Park or the state's attorney of
Kankakee County may commence an action to abate public nuisance as described
above. Upon being satisfied by affidavits or other sworn evidence that an
alleged public nuisance exists, the court may without notice or bond enter a
temporary restraining order or a preliminary injunction to enjoin any defendant
from maintaining such nuisance and may enter an order restraining any defendant
from removing or interfering with all property used in connection with the
public nuisance. (Ord. 02-4-15-2, 4-15-2002)
6-1-4-5: PROCEDURE:
When the chief of police of the village of Grant Park receives two (2) or more
police reports documenting the occurrence of nuisance activity on or within a
property, the chief of police shall independently review such reports to
determine whether they describe criminal acts. Upon such findings, the chief
may:
   (A)   Notify the person in charge in writing that the property is in danger
of becoming a chronic nuisance property. The notice shall contain the following
information:
      1.   The street address or a legal description sufficient for
identification of the property.
      2.   A statement that the chief of police has information that the
property may be chronic nuisance property, with a concise description of the
nuisance activities that may exist, or that have occurred. The chief of police
shall offer the person in charge an opportunity to propose a course of action
that the chief of police agrees will abate the nuisance activities giving rise
to the violation.
      3.   Demand that the person in charge respond to the chief of police
within ten (10) days to discuss the nuisance activities.
   (B)   After complying with the notification procedures described herein when
the chief of police receives a police report documenting the occurrence of a
third nuisance activity at or within a property and determines that the
property has become a chronic nuisance property, the chief of police shall:
      1.   Notify the person in charge in writing that the property has been
determined to be a chronic nuisance property. The notice shall contain the
following information:
         (a)   The street address or legal description sufficient for
identification of the property.
         (b)   A statement that the chief of police has determined the property
to be chronic nuisance property with a concise description of the nuisance
activities leading to his/her findings.
         (c)   Demand that the person in charge respond within ten (10) days to
the chief of police and propose a course of action that the chief of police
agrees will abate the nuisance activities giving rise to the violation.
         (d)   Service shall be made either personally or by first class mail,
postage prepaid, return receipt requested, addressed to the person in charge at
the address of the property believed to be a chronic nuisance property, or such
other place which is likely to give the person in charge notice of the
determination by the chief of police.
         (e)   A copy of the notice shall be served on the owner at such
address as shown on the tax rolls of the county in which the property is
located, and/or the occupant, at the address of the property, if these persons
are different than the person in charge, and shall be made either personally or
by first class mail, postage prepaid.
         (f)   A copy of the notice shall also be posted at the property after
ten (10) days has elapsed from the service of mailing of the notice to the
person in charge and the person in charge has not contacted the chief of
police.
         (g)   The failure of any person to receive notice that the property
may be a chronic nuisance property shall not invalidate or otherwise affect the
proceedings under this chapter.
      2.   If after the notification, but prior to the commencement of legal
proceedings by the village pursuant to this article, a person in charge
stipulates with the chief of police that the person in charge will pursue a
course of action the parties agree will abate the nuisance activities giving
rise to the violation, the chief of police may agree to postpone legal
proceedings for a period of not less than ten (10) nor more than thirty (30)
days, except in the case of a nuisance activity under section 3(b)(7) where a
search warrant was executed at the property. If the agreed course of action
does not result in the abatement of the nuisance activity or if no agreement
concerning abatement is reached within thirty (30) days, the chief of police
shall request authorization for the village attorney to commence a legal
proceeding to abate the nuisance.
      3.   Concurrent with the notification procedures set forth herein, the
chief of police shall send copies of the notice, as well as, any other
documentation which supports legal proceedings to the village attorney.
   (C)   When a person in charge makes a response to the chief of police as
required above, any conduct or statements made in connection with the
furnishing of that response shall not constitute an admission that any nuisance
activities have or are occurring. This subsection does not require the
exclusion of any evidence which is otherwise admissible or offered for any
other purpose. (Ord. 02-04-15-2, 4-15-2002)
6-1-4-6: COMMENCEMENT OF ACTION; BURDEN OF PROOF:
   (A)   In an action seeking closure of a chronic nuisance property, the
village shall have the initial burden of showing by preponderance of the
evidence that the property is a chronic nuisance property.
   (B)   It is a defense to an action seeking the closure of chronic nuisance
property that the owner of the property at the time in question could not, in
the exercise of reasonable care or diligence, determine that the property had
become a public nuisance property, or could not, in spite of the exercise of
reasonable care and diligence, control the conduct leading of the findings that
the property is a chronic nuisance property.
   (C)   In establishing the amount of any civil penalty requested, the court
may consider any of the following factors if they need be found appropriate,
and shall cite those found applicable:
      1.   The actions or lack of action taken by the person in charge to
mitigate or correct the problem at the property.
      2.   Whether the problem at the property was repeated or continuous.
      3.   The magnitude or gravity of the problem.
      4.   The cooperation of the person in charge with the village.
      5.   The cost of the village investigating and correcting or attempting
to correct the condition. (Ord. 02-04-15-2, 4-15-2002)
6-1-4-7: EMERGENCY CLOSING PROCEDURES:
   (A)   In the event that it is determined that the property is an immediate
threat to the public safety and welfare, the village may apply to the court for
such interim relief, as is deemed by the chief of police to be appropriate. In
such an event, the notification provision set forth in section
6-1-4-5 of this article need not be complied with; however, the village shall
make a diligent effort to notify the person in charge prior to a court hearing.
   (B)   In the event that the court finds the property constitutes a "chronic
nuisance property" as defined in this article, the court may order the remedy
set out above. In addition, in the event that it also finds the person in
charge had knowledge of activities or conditions of the property constituting
or violating this article and permitted the activities to occur, the court may
assess a civil fine as provided above.
   (C)   The court may authorize the village of Grant Park to physically secure
the property against use or occupancy in the event the owner fails to do so
within the time specified by the court. In the event that the village is
authorized to secure the property, all costs reasonably incurred by the village
to effect a closure shall be made and assessed as a lien against the property.
If used herein, "costs" mean those costs actually incurred by the village for
the physical securing of the property as well as tenant relocation costs
   (D)   The village of Grant Park department of public works effecting the
closure shall prepare a statement of cost and the village of Grant Park shall
thereafter submit said statement to the court for its review. If no objection
of the statement is made within the period described by the court, a lien in
said amount may be recorded against said property.
   (E)   Any person who is assessed the cost of closure and/or civil penalty by
the court shall be personally liable for the payment thereof by the village.
   (F)   A tenant is entitled to their reasonable relocation costs, as those
are determined by the court if, without actual notice, the tenant moved into
the property after either:
      1.   The owner or tenant received notice of an action brought pursuant to
this section.
      2.   Unknown owner or other agent received notice of an action brought
pursuant to this section.
   (G)   Any person who is assessed with costs of closure and/or civil penalty
by the court shall be personally liable for the payment thereof to the village.
(Ord. 02-04-15-2, 4-15-2002)
CHAPTER 2
GARBAGE, RUBBISH
SECTION:
6-2-1: Short Title
6-2-2: Definitions
6-2-3: Unlawful Deposits
6-2-4: Burning
6-2-5: Collection by Scavenger
6-2-6: Approval Required; Hauling Garbage
6-2-7: Garbage Receptacles; Regulations
6-2-8: Loading Area Clearance
6-2-9: Disturbing Contents
6-2-10: Contract for Collection, Disposal
6-2-11: Supervise Collection, Disposal
6-2-12: Garbage Grinders, Incinerators
6-2-13: Billing
6-2-1: SHORT TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known and cited as the "Garbage Ordinance." (R.O. 1974,
Sec. 6.7.22)
6-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
ALLEY: Any public or private way, other than a street, giving access to the
rear of lots or buildings.
APARTMENT HOUSE: A building or portion thereof containing two (2) or more
dwelling units.
COLLECTION UNIT: One box or carton empty or filled with rubbish. The term shall
also apply to rubbish in general when such materials are disassembled, broken
or cut up and placed in securely tied bundles. All collection units shall be
securely tied by the occupant and shall be of a size that the longest dimension
thereof shall not exceed three feet (3') and provided further that the total
weight of any single unit shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds. The term shall
also include water tanks up to and including thirty (30) gallons capacity.
GARBAGE: Every accumulation of animal, fruit, food and vegetable waste from the
preparation, processing, cooking, consumption, storage or handling of animal
meats, fish, fowl, fruit and vegetables other than those wastes described in
the definition of rubbish. "Garbage" shall also mean small dead animals
weighing not over fifteen (15) pounds and waste from restaurants, cafeterias
and diners.
GARBAGE CAN: A round, water tight, sheet metal or comparable material, raised
bottom container not exceeding thirty three (33) gallons in capacity, weighing,
without cover, not over twenty six (26) pounds when empty, fitted with two (2)
sturdy handles, one on each side, and a tight cover equipped with a handle. The
term shall also apply to other containers which are water and vermin proof when
approved by the Village Board.
GARBAGE DISPOSAL SITE: The area owned or leased or used by the contractor
scavenger for the disposal of garbage, rubbish and trade waste collected in the
Village. This site shall not be within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the
Village limits.
RESIDENCE: A building or portion thereof containing no more than one dwelling
unit.
RUBBISH: Discarded nonrotting waste matter including, but not limited to,
ashes, yard trimmings, household furnishings, paper, boxes, bottles, other
containers or rags, earth, sand, building materials, automobiles or large parts
of cars and metal.
STREET: A public or private way, other than an alley used for public travel.
TRADE WASTE: Any waste materials from factories, processing plants,
manufacturing plants, commercial establishments, service stations or garages.
VILLAGE CONTRACTOR SCAVENGER: The one contracting with the Village to collect
and dispose of garbage, rubbish and trade waste as herein described, or
authorized representatives of such collector. (1974 Code § 6.7.5; amd. Ord., 9-
19-1994)
6-2-3: UNLAWFUL DEPOSITS:
It is unlawful to deposit, throw or place any "garbage", "rubbish", refuse or
"trade waste" as herein defined on any property, public or private, or in any
alley, street or public place, except in garbage cans or in collection units,
as hereinafter described, placed on private property or on the street or alley.
Such cans shall be kept tightly covered and covers shall not be removed except
when necessary. (1974 Code § 6.7.1)
6-2-4: BURNING:
   (A)   Permissible Burning:
Fireplaces.
Recreational wood burners.
Residential campfires.
Wood burning stoves.
   (B)   Prohibited: It shall be found unlawful to burn any garbage or refuse
or to burn any other combustible materials of any source or nature within the
Village limits at any time. Burning of leaves, grass and compost is prohibited.
No person shall burn any leaves, grass or compost within the Village at any
time. (Ord. 11-04-04-1, 4-4-2011)
   (C)   Penalty: Any person who violates this section shall be fined as set
forth in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 11-04-04-1, 4-4-2011; amd. Ord. 11-11-07-1, 11-7-
2011)
6-2-5: COLLECTION BY SCAVENGER:
All "garbage", "rubbish" and "trade waste", as herein defined, which
accumulates in the Village, shall be collected by the Village contractor
scavenger from all premises public and private. (1974 Code § 6.7.3)
6-2-6: APPROVAL REQUIRED; HAULING GARBAGE:
It shall be unlawful for anyone except the Village contractor scavenger to haul
garbage in the Village, except with the prior and specific approval of the
Village Board. (1974 Code § 6.7.4)
6-2-7: GARBAGE RECEPTACLES; REGULATIONS:
   (A)   All premises, public and private, must have and use a sufficient
number of garbage cans to hold all their garbage and ashes.
   (B)   No garbage shall be placed in boxes or collection units. Dumpsters or
mobile garbage bins designed to be brought and/or taken away by a special truck
are prohibited upon all premises zoned residential, including single-family,
multi-family and/or apartment residence buildings. This shall not prohibit
their use when previously approved by the Village Board upon the issuance of a
permit for special purposes limited to a defined timeframe, including but not
limited to construction, renovation, moving, or other related special projects.
   (C)   No hot ashes shall be placed in a garbage can.
   (D)   All garbage cans shall be kept in good condition for garbage
collection and handling. No garbage can which leaks or has jagged holes or
edges shall be used.
   (E)   No garbage can, when filled, shall weigh more than fifty (50) pounds,
and it shall be so packed that the contents thereof will dump out readily when
the can is inverted.
   (F)   All garbage cans and collection units shall be placed by the occupant
in convenient, accessible locations upon the ground level or ground floor as
near as possible to the approximate rear of the building, or near the alley or
such other locations as may be approved by the Village Board. For those
premises that have no alley, the material shall be placed in the street
directly in front of the property concerned, but it shall not be placed there
until a reasonable time before collection and removed within a reasonable time
after collection. (Ord. O-10-16-2, 10-10-2016)
6-2-8: LOADING AREA CLEARANCE:
All walks, paths and driveways to the place of loading shall have an overhead
clearance of not less than eight feet (8'). (1974 Code § 6.7.12)
6-2-9: DISTURBING CONTENTS:
It shall be unlawful, except as authorized by the occupant of the premises, or
the Village, to deposit any material into any garbage can or to remove the
cover therefrom or to remove or disturb the contents thereof except for
collection. (1974 Code § 6.7.13)
6-2-10: CONTRACT FOR COLLECTION, DISPOSAL:
The Village Board is hereby authorized and directed to call for bids for the
collection and disposal of garbage, rubbish and trade waste in accordance with
the specifications and forms of the contract. The Village Board is authorized
to award a contract to the lowest and best bidder or to reject any or all bids,
and to execute the same for the Village. (1974 Code § 6.7.14; amd. 1975 Code)
6-2-11: SUPERVISE COLLECTION, DISPOSAL:
The Village Public Works Superintendent is hereby authorized and directed to
supervise and manage the collection and disposal of all wastes produced in the
Village and shall have the general charge of and supervision over the handling
and administration and enforcement of this chapter. (1974 Code § 6.7.15)
6-2-12: GARBAGE GRINDERS, INCINERATORS:
Approved garbage grinders and approved incinerators are permissible, provided
that they are kept in good repair. (1974 Code § 6.7.16)
6-2-13: BILLING:
All users of this service shall be billed on a monthly basis by the Village in
conjunction with water and sewer billing. The Village Board may collect up to
ten percent (10%) in excess of the actual billing to allow for administration
and collection of defaults. (1974 Code § 6.7.17)
CHAPTER 3
SEPTIC TANK, CESSPOOL CLEANING
SECTION:
6-3-1: License Required
6-3-2: Application; Fee
6-3-3: Vehicle Regulations
6-3-4: Revocation
6-3-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use in the Village of any motor
vehicle for the carrying or storage of waste matter removed from any cesspool,
private sewage disposal plant, septic tank or outhouse unless a license for
such vehicle is first secured, under the license laws of the State of Illinois.
(R.O. 1974, Sec. 6.3.1)
6-3-2: APPLICATION; FEE:
Application for such license shall be made to the Village Clerk and shall
recite the name and address of the owner of such vehicle, the name or names of
the person or persons who shall operate said vehicle, the capacity and make of
said vehicle and the equipment thereon and shall be accompanied with a policy
of insurance insuring payment by the licensee of damages to persons and
property in a sum not less than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00). The
application shall further be accompanied by a good and sufficient surety bond
in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) to insure the compliance of the
licensee with the regulations stated herein. The annual fee for such license
shall be forty dollars ($40.00) for each vehicle and shall be issued for one
year. Such fee shall be paid to the Village Clerk who shall turn them over to
the Village Treasurer, forthwith. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 6.3.3)
6-3-3: VEHICLE REGULATIONS:
Every owner or operator of such licensed vehicle used as set forth in Section
6-3-1 herein, shall only operate said motor vehicle within the Village between
the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. for the
purpose of removing waste from septic tanks, cesspools and outhouses and shall
not park or allow said vehicle to stand in the business district or residential
district of the Village for more than one hour during said hours unless being
used at said time for the removal of said waste matter. No owner or operator of
such vehicle, whether licensed or not, shall allow said vehicle to remain
within the corporate limits of the Village between the hours of six o'clock (6:
00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M., nor park said vehicle within one-half (1/
2) mile of the Village limits. The owner or operator of any such vehicle used
for the purpose aforesaid shall in no event dispose of any waste or other
debris removed from any septic tank, cesspool or outhouse in the Village limits
or within one-half (1/2) mile of the Village limits, and shall not dispose of
any waste in any stream or watercourse which flows to within one-half (1/2)
mile of the Village limits. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 6.3.2)
6-3-4: REVOCATION:
Any license issued under the provisions of this Chapter may be revoked by the
President for any violation of any regulations hereof, and such revocation
shall be in addition to any fine imposed by this Chapter. (R.O. 1974, Sec.
6.3.5)
TITLE 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Sidewalks   1
Trees and Shrubs   2
Combined Waterworks and Sewerage System   3
Encroachments   4
On-Site Wastewater Disposal Zone   5
Sewer Use; Wastewater Disposal   6
CHAPTER 1
SIDEWALKS
SECTION:
7-1-1: Construction Specifications, Restrictions
7-1-2: Grade Established
7-1-3: Unsafe Sidewalks; Repair
7-1-4: Obstructing Sidewalks
7-1-5: Water Drainage
7-1-6: Snow and Ice Removal
7-1-7: Injure Curb or Sidewalk
7-1-8: Penalty
7-1-1: CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS, RESTRICTIONS:
   (A)   Width: On all streets or avenues within the Village, except streets
devoted to business, sidewalks shall be laid at a width of not less than four
feet (4'), and on all business streets and avenues, sidewalks shall be laid
from the property line to the line of the building. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 13.1.1)
   (B)   Private Use, Entrances: No part of any sidewalk will be taken for
private use by elevating or cutting down the same next to the building fronting
thereon, or by railing off the same with an iron or other railing or otherwise
shutting off the public from using the same, but said sidewalk shall be built
on the uniform grade, as hereinbefore provided. Entrances to cellars and
basements to buildings and flights of stairs, or steps may be made which shall
not extend into or on the sidewalk more than four feet (4'), but next to the
building, and the width of the steps, stairs or entrance in sidewalks to the
cellars or basements shall not be more than five feet (5'), and the same shall
at all times be securely protected by the owner or occupant of the building, so
as to protect and prevent persons traveling on such sidewalks from becoming
injured by such projection. Whoever shall violate this provision of this
subsection shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00)
nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. (Ord., 9-19-94)
   (C)   Extensions; Glass or Metal: No person shall build or extend any
sidewalk beyond the established width and no person shall insert any smooth
glass or metal in any sidewalk whatever. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 13.1.5)
   (D)   Steps, Platforms: No steps, platforms or other fixtures shall extend
into or upon any sidewalk or alleyway in the Village. No open cellar or
basement way shall be allowed in any sidewalk of the Village, except in
basements used by business therein, requiring the attendance of the same during
normal business hours. In all cases the basement stairways leading into
basements occupied for business as aforesaid shall have substantial iron guards
or railings on the sides of said stairway on the sidewalk side. (R.O. 1974,
Sec. 13.1.7)
7-1-2: GRADE ESTABLISHED:
   (A)   The President and Trustees shall establish a grade for all sidewalks
and the same shall conform as nearly as possible to the grade of their
respective streets. Where no permanent grade is established, they may give
temporary grade and shall, when requested by any person desiring to build a
sidewalk, stake out the grade with the understanding that the Village shall
make a charge to such person. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 13.1.2)
   (B)   No person shall construct or lay or cause to be constructed or laid
any sidewalk where no grade has been established by the Village without having
first obtained a grade therefor from the Village, or shall construct or cause
to be constructed any sidewalk contrary to any established grade which has been
or may thereafter be established by said Board of Trustees, under a penalty of
fifty dollars ($50.00) fine. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on
each day during or on which such person shall fail to make the sidewalk conform
to proper grade. (Ord., 9-19-94)
7-1-3: UNSAFE SIDEWALKS; REPAIR:
   (A)   Every sidewalk in the Village which is so much worn or out of repair
as to endanger the safety of persons passing over the same, is hereby declared
a nuisance, and any person who shall suffer or permit such nuisance to exist in
front of or adjoining his premises owned or occupied by him shall be subject to
fine under this chapter, after such person has been notified in writing by the
village clerk or the president or any member of the board of trustees, that
such a condition exists. In the event the owner or occupant of the property so
stated does not take time and steps to repair such defects and abate such
nuisance without delay, the village has the right to abate and repair the same
and send charges for this service to the property owner or take lien on said
property for such repair. (1974 Code § 13.1.6)
   (B)   The village shall help the property owner to see that the sidewalks
are kept in good repair, and in an effort to do the same, shall reimburse the
property owner in an amount equal to fifty percent (50%) of the cost for the
repair or reconstruction of any sidewalk within the village. This payment shall
not be made for new sidewalk construction in conjunction with the construction
of a new building or to contractors who are asking for consideration of new
annexation of property in subdivision type form. (Ord. 10-07-06-1, 7-6-2010)
7-1-4: OBSTRUCTING SIDEWALKS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, set or hand over or upon
any sidewalk in the village any goods, wares or merchandise, except within four
feet (4') distance from the building occupied by him, and also it shall be
unlawful for any person to erect, place or suspend any sign, flag, banner,
showcase or any other picture projecting into or handing over any sidewalk in
the village, exceeding four feet (4') distance from the building or premises
owned or occupied by such person. (1974 Code § 13.1.8; amd. 1975 Code)
   (B)   No person shall encumber or obstruct more than four feet (4') of the
outer edge of the sidewalk with goods, wares, merchandise, fuel or other
articles he may receive in the course of his business, or which may be
delivered in the due course of his business. (1974 Code § 13.1.9)
7-1-5: WATER DRAINAGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to suffer or permit the water falling or
draining from the roof of any building owned or occupied by them to spread over
the sidewalk in front of such building, and any person violating the provisions
of this section shall be deemed guilty of maintaining a nuisance. (1974 Code §
13.1.10)
7-1-6: SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL:
Every owner or occupant of any building or lessee of any enclosed lot or
premises and every person having charge or control of any church, hall or
public building shall, during the winter months, whenever there is a fall of
snow, and then by ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. on each day thereafter, clear the
sidewalk in front of the property named above from snow and ice and keep the
same reasonably free of the same, or shall in case the snow and ice are so
congealed as to cause difficulty to removal or injury to the sidewalk, see that
a covering of ice melting salt is spread thereover making the sidewalk as safe
as possible for use. (1974 Code § 13.1.11)
7-1-7: INJURE CURB OR SIDEWALK:
It shall be unlawful for any person within the village to cut, mar, break,
deface or in any way disfigure or injure any curb or sidewalk within the
village. (1974 Code § 13.1.12)
7-1-8: PENALTY:
Any person found in violation of any section of this chapter shall pay a fine
of not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by a sentence of
confinement in the village or county jail not to exceed six (6) months, or by
both such fine and imprisonment, unless otherwise provided. (1974 Code §
13.1.14; amd. 1975 Code)
CHAPTER 2
TREES AND SHRUBS
SECTION:
7-2-1: Planting Specifications
7-2-2: Removal by Village
7-2-3: Permission to Remove
7-2-4: Trimming Trees
7-2-5: Penalty
7-2-1: PLANTING SPECIFICATIONS:
Any person owning or having control of any lot, land or parcel of ground
adjoining or abutting any public street or avenue in the Village may plant
trees nine feet (9') from the lot line adjoining on any street or avenue within
the Village. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 16.1.1)
Any person who shall plant in any street or avenue of the Village any tree or
shrub further from or at a less distance than nine feet (9') from the lots
lines along any public street or avenue in the Village shall be fined under
this Chapter for every tree or shrub permitted to remain after notice to remove
the same has been given by the Street Commissioner, the President of the Board
or by any one of the Trustees of the Village. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 16.1.2)
7-2-2: REMOVAL BY VILLAGE:
It shall be the duty of the Street Commissioner to remove any tree or shrub
that shall hereafter be planted in violation of the provisions of this Chapter.
(R.O. 1974, Sec. 16.1.3)
7-2-3: PERMISSION TO REMOVE:
No person, except in compliance with this Chapter, shall cut, fell, injure or
remove any shade or other tree standing in or upon any street, avenue, sidewalk
or public ground in the Village, unless by the authority of the Board of
Trustees, under penalty of this Chapter. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 16.1.4)
7-2-4: TRIMMING TREES:
   (A)   All trees planted, cultivated or maintained in the Village along any
street or avenue, after having reached a suitable growth, shall have the
branches thereof cut and properly trimmed at a reasonable height from the
ground, and when of a suitable growth, trimmed at least ten feet (10') above
ground, so as not to interfere or encumber the passage of persons along the
sidewalks and cars along the streets or avenues, and so as not to obscure the
reflections of public street lights. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 16.1.5)
   (B)   If any tree shall be permitted by the owner or occupant of the
property to grow in such a way as to interfere with travel on any street,
avenue or sidewalk or so as to obstruct the light from any public street lamp,
it shall be the duty of the Village to notify such person, owner or occupant,
in writing, to trim such tree or trees within a time and in such a manner to be
specified in such notice. If such person so notified shall neglect or refuse to
comply with such notice, he shall be liable for any charges that the Village
may incur in having this work done for him, in behalf of the public safety and
welfare, in addition to any fine imposed by the terms of any Section of this
Chapter. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 16.1.6)
7-2-5: PENALTY:
If any person is found to be guilty of any violation of any Section of this
Chapter, he shall be liable for a fine not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (R.O.
1974, Sec. 16.1.7)
CHAPTER 3
COMBINED WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM 1 , 2
SECTION:
7-3-1: Systems Combined
7-3-2: Definitions
7-3-3: Supervisor Of The Combined Waterworks And Sewerage System
7-3-4: Regulations For Maintenance And Operation

7-3-6: Rates
7-3-7: Tapping Lines; Excavations
7-3-8: Default Of Payment
7-3-9: Reserved
7-3-10: Injure, Remove Sewerage Equipment
7-3-11: Repair And Liability To Village
7-3-12: Penalty
 
Notes

  6-1-2-12 of this code.

  7-6-9(F) of this title regarding fees.
7-3-1: SYSTEMS COMBINED:
It is hereby determined and declared to be necessary and in the best interest
of the public and of the village that the waterworks and sewerage systems of
the village be and are hereby combined and shall hereafter be maintained and
operated as a combined waterworks and sewerage system. (1974 Code § 8.1.1)
7-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
SEWERAGE SYSTEM: As used herein, means and includes the existing collection,
intercepting and outlet sewer, lateral sewers and drains, including the
combined stormwater and sanitary drains, and all other appurtenances necessary
or useful in connection therewith, and shall include any future alterations,
extensions, improvements or additions thereto.
WATERWORKS: Means and includes the existing waterworks system of the village in
its entirety, and any integral part thereof, including pumps, machinery, wells,
storage and pressure tanks, distribution system, hydrants, meters, valves and
all other elements necessary or useful in connection therewith, and shall
include any future alterations, extensions, improvements or additions thereto.
(1974 Code § 8.1.2)
7-3-3: SUPERVISOR OF THE COMBINED WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM:
   (A)   The combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village shall be
managed by the supervisor who shall be appointed, subject to the approval of a
majority of the board of trustees, on or before May 1 in each year, except for
the first such appointment hereunder, which shall be made forthwith following
the effective date hereof. Such officer shall be known as and is hereby
designated as "supervisor of the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the
village of Grant Park, Illinois".
   (B)   The term of each such supervisor shall expire on April 30 next
following his appointment, except that each incumbent shall hold such office
until his successor shall have been appointed and shall have been duly
qualified. Such supervisor shall qualify, before entering upon his duties by
giving evidence to the board of trustees that he is competent to hold such
office.
   (C)   The compensation of such officer shall be fixed by the village board
of trustees.
   (D)   The supervisor shall be in charge of the enforcement of all
regulations adopted by the president and board of trustees of the village for
the maintenance and operation of the combined waterworks and sewerage system.
He shall be responsible for the preparation of all chemicals used and
introduced into the water supply. (1974 Code § 8.1.3)
7-3-4: REGULATIONS FOR MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION:
The following regulations for the maintenance and operation of the combined
waterworks and sewerage system are hereby adopted:
   (A)   Water: No permanent connection shall be made between the water
distribution system of the Village and the water supply and plumbing facilities
of any building serviced or to be served by the waterworks of the Village,
until there shall be installed all such fittings and equipment as the County or
Village inspectors shall say are needed and approved.
   (B)   No owner, tenant or occupant of any building serviced or to be served
as to water supply by the waterworks of the Village shall deny any authorized
employee or agent of the Village access to the water system of the building for
the purpose of inspection thereof during the daylight hours.
   (C)   Sewerage: No sanitary sewer outlet from any building shall be
connected to, with or into the sewerage system of the Village except an
overflow connection or outlet from a septic tank, which septic tank shall be
located upon the premises occupied by the building served or to be served by
such outlet and which septic tank shall be constructed of nonporous material
and of sufficient depth and capacity to allow reasonable treatment of the
sewerage from the building which it serves.
   (D)   All sanitary sewer connections, whether from buildings to septic tanks
or from septic tanks to the Village sewerage system shall be constructed of
hardened, nonporous tile or cast iron tubing, with sealed joints, and shall be
buried to a depth of not less than forty inches (40").
   (E)   No storm water collected upon the premises occupied by any building
serviced or to be served by the sewerage system of the Village shall be allowed
to flow into or through the septic tank by these buildings served or to be
served by the sewerage system of the Village.
   (F)   No waste water from any plumbing facility in any building served or to
be served by the sewerage system of the Village, containing oil, grease, fat or
particles of oily, greasy or fatty matter of any kind shall be caused to flow
into or through the septic tank on the premises occupied by the building served
or to be served by the sewerage system of the Village, unless such waste water
shall have first been flowed through a grease trap or the oil, grease, fat or
particles of oily, greasy or fatty matter be trapped therefrom. (R.O. 1974,
Sec. 8.1.4)
7-3-5: PERMITS; WATER AND SEWER CONNECTIONS:
   (A)   Water Connections
      1.   No person shall make or cause to be made any connection to, with or
into any water main or water distribution pipe belonging to the Village without
having first obtained a permit to do so.
Application therefor shall be made to the Village Building Inspector and shall
be accompanied by the permit fee hereinafter provided. Upon receipt of such
application the Building Inspector shall inspect the premises for which the
connection is requested and shall issue the permit only if the regulations set
forth under Section
7-3-4 hereof have been complied with.
      2.   In all instances where the water main or water supply pipe of the
Village lies on the same side of the street as is the building for which the
water connection is requested, the permit fee for a water connection is hereby
fixed at five hundred dollars ($500.00).
      3.   In all instances where the water main or water supply pipe of the
Village lies on the opposite side of the street as is the building for which
the water connection is requested, the permit fee for a water connection is
hereby fixed at five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord., 9-19-94)
      4.   The cost of all excavation, labor, materials and refill shall in
either case be borne by the applicant and a deposit of five hundred dollars
($500.00) will be required at this time to assure proper completion under
subsection
7-3-7(C) of this Chapter. When the terms of said subsection
 7-3-7(C) are approved by the Street Commission of the Village, the deposit
shall be refunded. It shall be the duty of the owner of the property to notify
the Street Commission of such construction and failure to do so shall
constitute forfeiture of the deposit due and further penalty under Section
7-3-11 of this Chapter. (Ord. 7-5-82, 6-5-82; amd. Ord., 1-7-85)
   (B)   Sewer Connections:
      1.   No person shall make or cause to be made any connection to, with or
into any water main or water distribution pipe belonging to the Village without
having first obtained a written permit to do so.
Application therefor shall be made to the Village Building Inspector of the
Combined Waterworks and Sewage System and shall be accompanied by the permit
fee hereinafter provided. Upon receipt of such application the Building
Inspector shall inspect the premises for which the connection is requested and
shall issue the permit only if the regulations set forth under Section
7-3-4 hereof have been complied with. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 8.1.5)
      2.   In all instances where the tile of the sewerage system of the
Village lies on the same side of the street as is the building for which the
outlet connection is requested, the permit fee for a sewer outlet connection is
hereby fixed at five hundred dollars ($500.00).
      3.   In all instances where the tile of the sewerage system of the
Village lies on the opposite side of the street as is the building for which
the outlet connection is requested, the permit fee for a sewer outlet
connection is hereby fixed at five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord., 9-19-94)
      4.   The cost of all excavation, labor, materials and refill shall in
either event be borne by the applicant. A deposit of five hundred dollars
($500.00) will be required at this time to assure proper completion under
subsection
7-3-7(C) of this Chapter. When the terms of subsection
7-3-7(C) are approved by the Street Commission of the Village, the deposit
shall be refunded. It shall be the duty of the owner of the property to notify
the Street Commission of such construction and failure to do so shall
constitute forfeiture of the deposit due and further penalty under Section
7-3-11 of this Chapter. (Ord. 7-5-82, 6-5-82; amd. Ord. 1-7-85)
   (C)   Requirements for Sewer Connections:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person, public or private to connect or
cause to be connected, any industrial or domestic waste into the existing storm
or existing field tile sewer system within the Municipality's boundary which
does not meet part 4 of chapter 3 of the Illinois Pollution Control Board
Regulations and for which a construction permit is required by the Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency, unless that construction permit is duly
obtained.
      2.   Any person violating this Chapter shall be fined not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed for each and every
day during which a violation continues or exists. (Ord., 9-19-94)
7-3-6: RATES:
   (A)   All users of the facilities for water distribution and supply and for
sewerage collection provided by the Village under the combined waterworks and
sewerage system shall be liable for and shall pay a reasonable compensation to
the Village for the use and service of the combined waterworks and sewerage
system, as hereby affixed.
   (B)   The classification of users and rates applicable shall be set for the
respective classifications by the Board of Trustees as contract and operation
costs of the system demand. The rate for all users shall be considered at the
time of the negotiations with the garbage scavenger collection contract, at the
beginning of every year. After the consideration of the Board, as to the cost
of operation and upkeep, bookkeeping and contract terms that may have to be
considered, the Board shall post with the Village Clerk, in the record of the
Village, the rate for water, sewerage and scavenger collection for the
forthcoming year. This rate information shall be published for the general
public before the time such rate information shall come into effect. At no
time, however, shall the addition of charges for bookkeeping, upkeep and
supervision of the Department exceed ten percent (10%) of the cost incurred
under new contract or of the operation expense for the year ending, for which
figures of operation and expense are available.
   (C)   The charges for water, sewerage and garbage rates shall be due and
payable on a monthly basis, the combined monthly rate to be concurrent with the
monthly periods effective for these rates. All rate due statements shall be
mailed within the first five (5) days of the month, or if possible, on the
first day of the month, and shall carry the printed clause that they be payable
by the twenty fifth day of the month. The Village shall have the right to
request that a ten percent (10%) penalty charge be payable with the billing, if
paid after the twenty fifth day of the month. (R.O. 1974, Sec. 81.6)
   (D)   All users of water and or sewer when such service is used and received
outside of the Village limits shall be charged the rate for "in Village"
service plus an additional fifty dollars ($50.00) per month. For each
subsequent six (6) month period fifty dollars ($50.00) will be added. (Ord., 5-
15-95)
7-3-7: TAPPING LINES; EXCAVATIONS:
   (A)   After agreement with, and payment of all the aforementioned fees for
connection, and the approval of the Board, the applicant may, at his expense,
make all excavations and place pipes, drains and other necessary materials
preparatory to the actual connections to the Village sewerage system lines. All
materials must be free from defects and shall conform to the requirements of
the American Society for Testing and Materials.
   (B)   Upon approval by the Village inspector of all excavations and
materials, the applicant may, at his expense, cause a tap to be made to the
Village sewerage system lines. The tap to the storm sewer lines may be made
only by a person or persons authorized and appointed by the Village to make
such taps.
   (C)   Upon approval of all taps to the Village sewer lines, the applicant
shall cause, at his expense, all excavations to be restored to their original
conditions. Backfills must be made of sand or stone screening and after being
approved, the deposit under section
7-3-5 of this chapter shall be refunded. (Ord. O-4-16-1, 4-4-2016)
7-3-8: DEFAULT OF PAYMENT:
   (A)   Billing:
      1.   Bills Due, Late Fee: Bills shall be rendered monthly and shall be
payable on the due date stated on the bill. Failure to receive a bill or not
reading a bill will not excuse a customer from his or her obligation to pay
within the time period specified. A ten percent (10%) late fee shall be added
to the bill if not paid within the said time period.
      2.   Delinquency:
         (a)   Late fees will be assessed when a sewer bill is overdue.
         (b)   At thirty (30) days, late fees are added to the bill along with
the new sewer charges. Included in the bill will be a copy of the ordinance and
consequences for continued non- payment.
         (c)   At sixty (60) days, if the outstanding sewer charges are not
current, the account goes into debt recovery.
         (d)   At ninety (90) days, if the outstanding sewer charges, including
late fees, are not current, the septic tank will be disconnected from the sewer
system and the residence and/or business will be considered uninhabitable.
         (e)   The cost of disconnection and reconnection will be added to the
existing sewer bill before the residence and/or business can be entered again.
This fee generally does not exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
      3.   Non-Sufficient Funds: Any person issuing a check or other draft,
including credit or debit card payment, to the Village of Grant Park that is
not honored upon presentation because the payee does not have an account, or
does not have sufficient funds in his account, shall be assessed a twenty five
dollar ($25.00) non-sufficient funds fee. Any obligation fee paid in such
manner shall remain outstanding and any penalties, interest, or fees will
continue to accrue until the Village receives funds for the outstanding amount
plus the non-sufficient funds fee. If payment was made in response to a
disconnection notice, such action shall proceed as if no payment had been made.
      4.   Filing Of Suit, Lien, Or Disconnection For Payment Default: The
Village shall have the right in the event of default on payment of any of the
aforesaid charges or services and as a condition to any person or corporation
using the aforesaid facilities in the event of a failure to pay the amount
billed, to file suit for collection, file a lien against the property being
serviced, pursue outside collection efforts and disconnect said service or any
combination thereof, all at the option of the Village.
   (B)   Late Payment Report: At the first Village Board meeting in the months
of March, June, September, and December, the Village Clerk shall report a full
list of the names of all users of the aforesaid charges or services which are
unpaid within thirty (30) days after the bill for services has become due. The
Village Clerk shall then publish a list of the names of all users who are more
than thirty (30) days late in the payment of the aforesaid charges or services
in a newspaper published in the Village and by posting a copy thereof in
Village Hall on March 15 and November 15 of each year. Additionally, the
Village may include the aforesaid list with the monthly bills issued to users
of Village sewer and garbage services in the billing cycle immediately
following the report of the Village Clerk.
   (C)   Reconnection Fee: In the event that sewer services are disconnected as
a result of nonpayment of sewer bills, sewer service shall not be reinstated
until all past due bills are paid in full, including a five hundred dollar
($500.00) reconnection fee, together with the reasonable costs incurred by the
Village in disconnecting or reinstating the service.
   (D)   Landlords, Property Owners And Tenants Jointly And Severally
Responsible For Water And Sewer Utility Bills:
      1.   Every landlord or property owner, and the occupant thereof, shall be
jointly and severally responsible for any utility charges or fees left unpaid
by any tenant of the premises served by the water or sewer utility; and the
water and sewer utility services shall be furnished to the premises by the
Village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant and
customer of the water service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the
Village. Further, where the landlord or property owner fails to pay the utility
charge(s), the Township may refuse to provide any water service to the property
with the delinquent charge even in the name of a subsequent tenant.
      2.   When a tenant is delinquent in payment for over thirty (30) days,
the Village shall make a good faith effort to notify the landlord or owner of
the premises receiving such service of the delinquency and the amount thereof.
Any notice of termination shall be sent to both the occupant and landlord or
owner of the premises receiving such service. If the Village shall fail to do
this, the failure will not relieve the tenant, landlord or owner of the
premises of his or her obligation to pay the delinquent account.
      3.   The landlord or property owner of any real estate may at any time,
whether a utility bill is current or delinquent, notify the Village in writing
that they request to have the water and/or sewer service to the premises
disconnected for a fee, and acknowledge that a subsequent reconnection of the
water service may require a reconnection charge as may be provided for
elsewhere in this Code. This section shall not be construed to allow the
landlord or owner of any property to procure the disconnection of sewer and/or
water service on said property against the will of any occupants thereof. (Ord.
O-10-16-3, 10-10-2016)
7-3-9: RESERVED:
(Ord. O-4-16-1, 4-4-2016)
7-3-10: INJURE, REMOVE SEWERAGE EQUIPMENT:
Any person who shall, within the Village, break, deface, injure or remove any
cap or coping stone or grate belonging to any catch basin, manhole, vent, inlet
or intake of any sewer belonging to the Village, or who shall, in any manner,
injure the mouth of such drain or sewer, shall for each offense be subject to a
fine specified in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (1974 Code § 12.5.2; amd. 1975 Code)
7-3-11: REPAIR AND LIABILITY TO VILLAGE:
   (A)   Sewer line problems that may occur because of tree or plant roots in
the system will become the liability of the Village only to the customer's
property line. (Ord. O-4-16-1, 4-4-2016)
7-3-12: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter, where no other penalty is
provided, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (11-15-56; amd. 1975 Code)
CHAPTER 4
ENCROACHMENTS
SECTION:
7-4-1: Definitions
7-4-2: Specifically Regulated Encroachments (Rep. by Ord., 9-19-94)
7-4-3: Encroachments Unlawful
7-4-4: Additional Ruling
7-4-5: Penalty
7-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
CONSTRUCTION EASEMENT AREA: The area lying between the project right-of-way
limits and the platted street limits within which the Village, by concurrence
in the establishment of the project right-of-way lines, will permit the State
to enter to perform all necessary construction operations.
ENCROACHMENT: Any building, fence, sign or any other structure or object of any
kind (with the exception of utilities and public road signs), which is placed,
located or maintained in, on, under or over any portion of the project right of
way or the roadway right of way where no project right-of-way line has been
established.
PERMISSIBLE ENCROACHMENT: Any existing awning, marquee, advertising sign or
similar overhanging structure supported from a building immediately adjacent to
the limits of the platted street where there is a sidewalk extending to the
building line and which does not impair the free and safe flow of traffic on
the highway, the permissive retention of overhanging signs is not to be
construed as being applicable to those signs supported from poles constructed
outside the project right-of-way line and not confined by adjacent buildings.
PROJECT RIGHT OF WAY: Those areas within the project right-of- way lines
established jointly by the Village and the State which will be free of
encroachments except as hereinafter defined.
ROADWAY RIGHT OF WAY: Those areas existing or acquired by dedication or by fee
simple for highway purposes; also, the areas acquired by temporary easement
during the time the easement is in effect. (Ord., 12-19-77)
7-4-2: SPECIFICALLY REGULATED ENCROACHMENTS:
(Rep. by Ord., 9-19-94)
7-4-3: ENCROACHMENTS UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect or cause to
be erected, to retain or cause to be retained, any encroachment within the
limits of the project right of way or roadway right of way where no project
right-of-way lines have been established. (Ord., 12-19-77)
7-4-4: ADDITIONAL RULING:
This Ordinance is intended to and shall be in addition to all other ordinances,
rules and regulations concerning encroachments and shall not be construed as
repealing or rescinding any other ordinance or part of any ordinance unless in
direct conflict therewith. (Ord., 12-19-77)
7-4-5: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation violating this Chapter shall be fined not less
than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed for each and
every day during which a violation continues or exists. (Ord., 9-19-94)
CHAPTER 5
ON-SITE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL ZONE
SECTION:
7-5-1: Formation
7-5-2: Public Benefit
7-5-3: Boundaries

7-5-1: FORMATION:
The President and Board of Trustees hereby declare the formation of an On-Site
Wastewater Disposal Zone (hereinafter called "Zone") pursuant to 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 90/1 through 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 90/22.
7-5-2: PUBLIC BENEFIT:
The President and Board of Trustees find that formation of an On-Site
Wastewater Disposal Zone and implementation of the recommendations of said
Facilities Plan will benefit the public by:
   (A)   Protecting the public health,
   (B)   Preventing and abating nuisances,
   (C)   Protecting existing and future beneficial water uses, and
   (D)   Achieving compliance with regulations of the Pollution Control Board
and other statutes or requirements regarding public health or environmental
protection.
